https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/327402.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight with a 2.78 lb eye of round roast.  I followed the directions exactly.  My roast went into a 500 degree oven at 4:04.  I then reduced to 475 for 19 minutes turned the oven off and it was at 140 degrees at 5:30!  I know, I know, thank god I had a thermometer in the meat or we would have had shoe leather for dinner.  I was shocked and my dinner timing was off.  I have a brand new oven that must hold heat really well.  My advice to folks who got a roast over cooked or undercooked get yourself a meat thermometer.  My other tip is to over season your roast like it is going to be over seasoned.  I put what I thought was a lot of seasoning, but the roast could have taken a lot more of salt, pepper and garlic powder.  I will make this again because it is easy, but I will gauge my time better.  Thanks for sharing.

userID:
2246007
Display Name:
Tracy
isPro:

12
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first time making a roast and it was a big success - it even works with an older electic stove. To prep, I rubbed the roast with olive oil and a little kosher salt, and pepper, stuffing minced garlic in about 10 holes throughout the roast. I placed the roast and about 1 cup of water in the bottom of a shallow casserole dish and after preheating to 500 for at least 15 minutes, I cooked my 2.6 lb roast fat side up for 22 minutes at 475.  Then, as directed, turned off the over and hoped that my 10 year old oven would do the trick.  After 2hrs and 15 minutes, I pulled it out, foil tented it, and let it rest for another 15 minutes. I then removed the roast from the dish, placed the dish on the stove on medium, and made gravy with the drippings by adding a little more flour and water and heating gently for about 10 minutes on the stove.  Sliced very thin and served with the gravy and potatoes and broccoli.  Perfect.  Thanks.
Review:

I'm giving it three starts because the timing didn't really work for me, although the flavor was good, we only tasted a slice or two of it last night and I'm going to try to slice it very thin today. It was a 2.5 lb. roast, so I cut the 2 1/2 hour standing time in the shut off oven down to about two hours. It was like totally rare in the center. So, I put it back in for around thirty minutes with the oven on at 300, then turned it off for another thirty minutes. It was much better. I used the seasoning from another reviewer with the ground up raisins, etc., that was pretty nice, i added a spash of olive oil to the mix.

text:
This was delicious; the flavor can't be beat!
I had a 4 pound roast, though, and cooked it for 28 minutes, then let sit in the over for 2 1/2 hours.  Since this (The sitting time) is the instructions for a 3 pounder, I thought mine would be good and pink, which is how I like it. Instead, it was very dry, and brown throughout.  Next time I will definitely use a probe or adjust the cooking time. As I said, though, the flavor of the meat was wonderful, there were enough pan drippings for a yummy gravy, and the middle pieces had some juice to them. 
I seasoned with kosher salt, pepper, garlic powder and onion powder.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I left my 3.3 lb eye of round roast out on the counter for an hour to come to room temp, then brushed lightly with gravy master liquid, let it soak in a bit, then blotted with paper towel so it wouldn't overpower and would still crisp up on the outside. Like others, I used extra seasoning (s&p, onion powder, garlic powder, celery salt, paprika powder), set my gas oven for 500, put the roast on a rack in a roasting pan, reduced the heat to 475 for 23 minutes, then reduced the temp to 180, for an hour. I checked after that first hour and my instant read thermometer was just above 130, exactly where I wanted it (we like rare beef, but not bloody). I took it out and let it rest under foil for around an hour. It was a perfect pink throughout, and crispy on the outside! I also used the "Beef Au Jus" recipe (slightly tweaked) from this site. Delicious!

text:
Delicious!  The success of this cooking method will depend upon how accurate the temperature of your oven is and how well your oven retains heat.  Adjust cooking time +/- according to your individual oven.  If you have a very old oven that is not well insulated, this recipe may not work for you, as heat retention/residual heat is IMPORTANT to the success of this recipe.  In addition, the meat MUST be completely THAWED and at ROOM TEMPERATURE, inside and out, before going in the oven.  Hope this helps!

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe several times now. It is AMAZING. Roll the roast very lightly in olive oil then load it up with seasoning salt--a lot of it cooks off, so you'll have it right just when you think you're starting to overdo it. Let your oven heat for an extra twenty minutes once it has 'preheated.' Seven minutes per pound first, then fifty minutes per pound once you turn off the oven. One you have taken it out, let it rest for ten minutes before cutting or serving.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
2382478
Display Name:
Liz
isPro:
False
followersCount:

36
favoritesCount:
142
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3588804.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe tonight after reading a number of reviews and loved it! Taking the advice of several reviewers, I left the fat on, rinsed and dried the meat, brushed the exterior with Gravy Master, then seasoned with salt, fresh ground pepper and garlic powder. Baked uncovered fat side up on a grill in a roasting pan at 500 degrees for 24 minutes for a three pound eye roast, then turned oven off for 2-1/2 hours. When I opened the oven afterward, it was cold (as mentioned by another reviewer, I don't think gas ovens hold the heat as well).  I made a judgment call and put it back in the oven for 20 minutes on 350 degrees.  Took out and let rest for another 20 minutes, then sliced to a beautiful assortment of medium and medium well done (more pink slices than red).   I and my guests enjoyed it tremendously, taking seconds as well. I cannot believe the ease of cooking this way. I added water to a small amount of drippings to make a small amount of gravy.  Can't wait to make it again now that I know it really works.  The finished product looked like a professional chef cooked it.

text:
I tried this recipe three months ago and the results were INCREDIBLE.  Never have we had such a delicious roast.  I coat mine with salt, pepper, a bit of thyme, marjoram, onion powder, garlic and cumin.  It sits overnight then I take it out to reach room temperature.  From there on, I follow the instructions to the letter.  It ALWAYS works, is ALWAYS perfect and we now make it for guests.

text:
Made this tonight for the very first time. I followed the tips from another review and brushed on Kitchen Bouquet, sprinkled some fresh ground sea salt and pepper, garlic powder, and I added a little onion powder. However, cooking it as directed per the recipe was far to pink for me, so I cooked for an additional 30 minutes on 450 F after it sat in the oven for the 2½ hours. It came out perfect. I served it with baked beans, green beans, and the roasted new potatoes (I added carrots too). The new potatoes recipe was on this site too. My husband said this was his favorite meal all year, and probably his new favorite. It was super easy to make, I'm not much of a cook and I think it turned out great!

Display Name:
Annie'sKitchen

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a 6lb roast, have a 1955 gas stove/oven which I have serviced every year to make sure it is up to par.  Oven/Stove Guy always tells me that if they made ovens/stoves the way they did back then, he would be out of business.  I wished I would have gone with my gut, but instead followed reviewers advice as far as "leaving the oven on at least 140F" for the next 2-1/2 hours because gas ovens don't retain heat. Used a bit of olive oil to coat roast then heavily seasoned with Kosher salt, pepper, fresh basil, oregano, thyme and rosemary placed in oven turned down to 475F and it smelled amazing.  I used the 7 min/lb. method (next time I will use 5min/lb. and then turn my oven off). I turned the oven down to 140F and luckily decided to check my roast after 1-1/2 hours.  The temp was already at 140F so I took out covered with foil loosely for approx. 20 min. and then began to carve. To my surprise, the roast was already medium to well done. We like rare! It still tasted/smelled AMAZING and there was a very small section of a faded pink left. Used the juice for gravy and it was AMAZING. Had a chunk of the roast left, two days later sliced it up very thin, heated AuJus to boiling, turned off, placed the thin slices in AuJus as needed and served to company. They LOVED IT Served with mashed potatoes, gravy and fresh spinach. I will definitely make again but use the 5min/lb. method and then TURN MY OVEN OFF! Apparently my oven retains heat JUST FINE! Thank YOU for this RECIPE! A++

text:
So this is probably the dumbest thing I have ever done, but it turned out awesome! I had a moment of total dizziness and FORGOT that I was cooking a PORK roast instead of a beef roast. I did everything the recipe said and tossed that bugger in there with salt, pepper, garlic powder, a little oregano and some chili powder and cooked it at 500 for 22 minutes before shutting it off. It sat in the oven for an hour and 15 minutes and it ended up coming out AMAZING! It was the most tender pork roast I've ever made. Who knew you could cook pork at a high temp and have it come out so amazingly moist and tender? I can't wait to try this recipe with a beef roast!

Cheers!

text:
Only OK.  I followed the instructions exactly and have a Jenn-aire electric oven.  It did not leave enough drippings for a gravy.  The roast was rare (bloody).  This was not nearly as good as my recipe.

Salt, pepper, and garlic powder eye of round roast.  Brown in small amount of oil.  When brown, add one can of beef broth and bake covered in a 300° oven for three hours.  The meat will be tender and will slice beautifully for sandwiches . . . and plenty of drippings for gravy.

text:
Wow!  This was so easy, tender, and so delicious!  Patience is the key, and resisting the urge to open the oven door.  Like others, preheated the oven at 500 degrees for 15-20 minutes, then roasted the seasoned 3.25 lb eye of the round for 7 mins per lb (approx 21 mins).  I then turned my gas oven down to 200 degrees for about 1.5 hours.  After taking it out, me meat thermometer read just under 145 degrees. I let it sit, covered for 15 minutes, then sliced thinly with my electric knife.  It turned out medium rare, and although at first I thought it might be a tad too rare, I received tons of raves.  Very, very good!

text:
We liked this.  I was looking for a recipe to use an eye of round roast with; I had tried the Prime Rib Roast method this way.  I did take another reviewers advice (since I was short on time) and cook at 475 for the required number of minutes, then turned my oven temp back to 200 degrees. Since we like our meat med. well to well done, I allowed the meat to cook an additional 45 minutes at the 200 degree mark (and didn't open the oven door).  This brought the roast up to 72 degrees C and it was light pink in the middle.  Next time, I will likely cook the roast an extra 15-20 minutes to have this suit our needs.  I used Montreal steak spice to season the outside of the roast and put a little olive oil and balsamic vinegar on the roast prior to putting on spices and cooking.  This created a very juicy cut of meat; we were pretty pleased with this.

text:
A friend gave me this recipe back in the 80s and it has never failed me. There is one thing she adds that makes it even better. Take a knife and plunge it into down into the top of the roast in two places every inch or so. Then push a clove of garlic (halved lengthwise) down into this pouch into about the middle of the roast. Let the roast sit like this for an hour or so before cooking, or even overnight in the refrigerator. Remove the cloves as the finished roast is sliced.

text:
Made this today - 4 lb roast 28 minutes in the oven and then oven off for 2.5 hrs - locked the oven door to keep the peekers away and keep heat in. It came out perfect sliced thin with beef both poured over. Used garlic salt pepper and put slits in meat and stuffed some garlic gloves in. This one is a keeper - i have been trying many roast beef recipes and all dry and too well done or rare - this was just right for all. My original post was 10/2012 and just wanted to say I only cook roast beef like this now and making today for at least the 20th time and thought I would edit my post to add that tidbit also as a lot of others have posted 90 minutes after turning off is fine and the meat is still warm to eat which is what I just did for the first time with a 5lb roast

text:
I have accidently bought beef Eye of Round roasts several times. Usually no matter how I cook it, it comes out tough.

This recipe - it came out the least toughest I've ever had with this cut of beef! That being said, I had a 2.5 lb roast - cooked it for 7 mins per lb, then left it in the turned-off oven for 2 hours instead of 2.5 since it was 1/2 lb. smaller. Well, it ended up being medium-well done. Unfortunately, I like it rare to med-rare.

Next time I will try it like a previous person said: 20 mins. per lb. in turned-off oven.

text:
This is by far the easiest way to make a roast as long as you don't need your oven for a few hours!  I had my dinner timed out so that when the roast came out, I got the sides in, which were done in the amount of time for the roast to sit.  I used a combination of garlic powder, fresh ground pepper and some cajun seasoning all over the roast.  Everyone was wowed at how good it was.  I made the mistake of deciding to "sample" it to make sure it tasted okay and it melted in my mouth.  I ended up sampling about five times and dipped it in the juice that it cooked in.  I also followed another reviewers suggestion and put the fattiest side up.  It glazed beautifully.  We had leftovers because I cooked a really big roast for the amount of people eating and the leftovers were still awesome, which says a lot for a beef roast dish.  Not dry at all!

text:
Seems obvious in retrospect, but if you're cooking a smaller roast, pull it from the oven sooner than 2.5 hours.  I made a 2.5lb eye round roast using this method, and after giving it the full 2.5 hours, it was overcooked in the center (up to about 155).  Probably should have pulled it out 30-40 minutes sooner, I'm guessing.

Display Name:
cscott

country:
None
text:
This is literally the first time I've ever taken the time to write a review, but after making this today, I felt compelled to do so.  I followed the recipe almost exactly (only difference was I added garlic powder and onion powder).  I like medium-rare and if you follow this recipe, you will end up with well done.  The flavor is wonderful, but would have been even better had I not cooked it so long.  My piece of meat was 2 1/2 lbs, I started by cooking the suggested 7 minutes per pound (cooked mine 18 minutes) and then turned off the oven.  I actually took the roast out after 2 hours, not 2 1/2 and still had well done.  Next time, after I turn oven off, I will leave the roast in the oven one hour tops, cover roast (still in pan)with foil and leave on the counter to cook just a little more and tenderize (will allow at least 20 minutes for this last step...I promise, meat will be so much more tender if you have time to do it).  The juice that was left in the pan was so delicious and made this meat dish come together (my husband compared it to prime rib sauce).  Time was a big concern when I was making this, I was worried about it coming out overdone, and I was right.  Like I said, if you like medium-rare, stick to 1 hour...definitely not 2 1/2 hours.  Flavor was awesome...huge hit with my husband,5 year old son, and 4 year old daughter!

I struggled with getting the roast up to temp.  I followed the instructions, however, my roast was closer to 4 lbs so I tried to compensate and cook accordingly. text:
Packed this roast in Montreal Steak Seasoning (spice jar from Costco) and put in a large baggie for 3 hours. Dropped to room temperature and then followed the directions and the suggestions of other reviewers. I left my gas oven off for 1 hour after cooking it for 7 min a lb. and then turned the oven back on to 185 for the last 1 1/2 hours. Let it rest out of the oven on the stove top and then sliced super thin. Had a great dinner and wonderful sandwich meat for the next day. Served with a Red Tomato/Blue Cheese/Italian Dressing Salad and it was the perfect summer meal. Where was this when I was driving my kids to baseball/football etc. practices! Will become a staple!

This is the ONLY way you should cook Eye-of-Round roast. We use this method all the time. Results are always perfect!

The only change we do is to turn the oven back on, set to 450, while making the rest of dinner. When the oven reachs 450, out comes the roast. This warms up the roast again to a nice eating temperature.

Review:

dateLastModified:

userID:

Display Name:
booboofixa

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to admitt I was worried making this dish but I figured I would give it a whirl.  I followed some users advice and brushed my roast with browning sauce then made a powder blend of salt, pepper, granulated garlic and onion powder. I sprinkled that mixtuer all over the roast which was 6 lbs.  I preheat the oven to 500 for 20 min then put the roast in but I kept a meat thermometer in the fattest part of the roast.  I cooked at 500 for 42 minutes than let it stay in the oven.  The thermometer went off at 140* way before the 2 1/2 hour mark.  I would have had a really well done piece of meat if I left it in as long as this recipe said.  I reccomend this meathod but definately use a thermometer because the time definately varries depending on your oven.  The guests really loved it but the roast really needed to be a bit warmer because the timing was off because the roast did not need 2 and 1/2 hours.  This is why I give it a 4 instead of a 5 star rating.

text:
well... Im among the people who this didn't work for... I like one ladys idea of taking the roast out of the fridge a bit early and letting it warm up a bit. I might try it again that way because I really like the idea of using less energy to cook it. Maybe it works in only certain kinds of ovens? I followed the recipe exactly but when I opened the oven the oven was cold and the roast was cool, I moved it to the cutting board with my bear hands. When I cut it open it was too rare and I like rare meat. I reheated the oven to 500 and then put my lid on my pot and poped it back in turned the heat down to 475 and cooked it for another 20 min. It was done perfect on the inside after this but tough and overdone on the outside. Also we used a bit of salt on our slices because we like it that way.

text:
Well, my girlfriend told me about this recipe.  I couldn't remember the cut of meat, so I called her from the store- she tells me its a rump roast- so that is what I bought.  I get home and see it ssupposed to be Eye of round roast.  OOPS!  So I freeze it for another day.  I pull it out and thaw it.  Its a bit over 5 pounds and still a little frozen so I cut it in half, pat it dry, put on garlic salt & pepper and cook it for 35 minutes- 7 minutes per pound.  Let it stay in the off oven for 2.5 hours- take it out and it was PERFECT.  Beautiful.  I will never go back! Thanks for an awesome recipe- now we know it works for a rump roast too!

text:
Excellent.  Followed directions exactly.  I used a 2lb eye round roast so I put it in for 14 MINUTES at 475 and then turned the oven OFF for 1 HOUR 40 MINS.  I marinated the eye round roast in a packet of onion soup mix overnight and it was unbelievable.  Unsure of the turnout I went to a local wireless store (while the oven was off) and purchased a new wireless phone for my fiance in case the meal did not turn out well.  Afterall, it was a birthday dinner from me to her and my first time making a roast with such an inexpensive cut of meat.  The dinner was perfect and she liked the cell phone too...

text:
I prep the roast with kosher salt rub, cover with moist kitchen towel pop in coldest part of fridge for 2-3 days. WEIGH the meat before, and after!!!! The timing is to finished meat weight. Don't like so much salt..brush, or rince it off, pat dry, season, or not. Bring meat out for an hour or so prior to cooking!! Be sure of your oven temps.  EZ~~

So I didn't have the cook time + 2 1/2 hrs.  I like a medium roast so I cooked at 9 min/lb for my 2.3 lb roast.  I then put in 195 degree oven.  It was done in an hour and 15 minutes.  Instead of taking it out and tenting it I turned it off to make sides and that was wrong cuz it got med well.  But it was so good and so juicy.  Next time I will try the total shut off method or if I have to have the low oven method I will definitely take it out earlier.  This was a great recipe.  Used Montreal steak too and loved it.

text:
The flavor wasn't the best, but that was my fault - inadequately seasoned.  But for an eye to be as tender as this was is pretty amazing.  My roast was large - take advantage of extra time.  Also, my oven was cold at the end, so the roast was a well ... easily remedied by turning it up for a little while, just to heat, and then letting it rest in the oven for a very short time, then out.  This is all going to depend on everyone's oven, though.  All in all ...GREAT.  Will definitely do this again ... and I made a big roast so that there was enough for the Beef Potpie recipe from this site with the leftovers.  Not bad for a meat that's less than $2/pound in this economy!

country:
None
text:
I've only just started to get into cooking.  When I told my wife what I was making--and more importantly HOW I was going to make it--she was just as skeptical as all of the other reviewers seemed to have been before they actually tried this recipe.  My meat thermometer never reached the 140 degrees referenced in the recipe.  So, I was worried that it would not be done enough.  However, I decided to stick it out and not vary from the recipe.  I did introduce minimal originality on the seasoning.  I lightly rubbed the beef with Worcestershire sauce and soy sauce.  Then, I rubbed in moderate amounts of salt, pepper, and Montreal Steak Rub.  But, that's really it.  My wife and I were both very doubtful about whether the high-temp approach would actually work, but were quickly won over once we took the roast out of the oven, sliced it and enjoyed its tender consistency, moist texture, and excellent flavor.  I will forever fix eye of round roast this way going forward.  Thanks, so much, to the source of this recipe.

text:
This is a great recipe if you have a meat slicer.  First i select a combination of spices that I like and spread them in a cake pan the size of the roast.  I then roll my roast in the spices.  This evenly coats the whole roast and doesn't waste a lot of spices.  I set a baking rack inside my roasting pan and follow the directions.  This makes an excellent roast beef sandwich.

text:
This was awesome. I wasn't sure how it would turn out, I'd never heard of making a roast this way. This roast turned out SO incredibly tender and was done perfectly.

I coated the roast with worchestershire sauce, then a tiny bit of tenderizer. Then I rubbed it with a little olive oil, and rubbed kosher salt, fresh cracked pepper and really finely minced red onion and garlic all over the entire roast.

The flavor was AMAZING and went right down in to the center of the meat (I didn't poke it). I think it's because of the cooking method. This recipe absolutely will become a staple in our house - thanks!! Also, thanks for giving clear cooking times (7 minutes/pound) because our roast was 1.7 pounds and it was extremely useful to know how long to leave it at 425. 

Best roast I've probably ever had! Every single person was raving about it all meal long and the rest of the evening. Not many meals do that, but this one does.

userID:
15942216
Display Name:
BLR123
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
28
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cooking a less tender cut of beef using this method produces a juicier, more tender result than just roasting it the traditional way.  I preheated my gas oven to 500 for 20 minutes. Turned it down to 475 and cooked my 1.72 pound roast for 12 minutes (7 minutes per pound).  Turned oven to 200 and cooked an additional 34 minutes (20 minutes per pound).  Tented it with foil, turned the oven off and let it rest in the oven for 30 minutes. It came out medium rare with enough juices to make an awesome gravy.  Don't be afraid to try this one. As others have mentioned, if you have a gas oven try dropping the temperature to around 200 and cooking 20 minutes per pound for the final cooking rather than turning the oven off and letting it sit for a couple of hours. Gas ovens have a tendency to cool much quicker than electric. You'll just have to tweak it depending on your oven, however, the basic high heat-low heat method is spot on.  I have also used this cooking method for prime rib and the result was just as amazing.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-06-09T11:12:48.737
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
15149235
Display Name:
John Krebs
isPro:
False

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1943271.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe works so well that I now use no other for this inexpensive cut of meat.  I submit the following possible explanations for those who have had failures:

1) Did not follow instructions precisely!
2) Did not calculate cooking time correctly based on weight of roast.
3) Modified cooking instructions (because thought too simple?).
4) Opened oven during cooking or resting time to check on roast.
5) Cut meat before or during resting time.
6) Knife not sharp enough to cut meat thinly.
7) Did not cut across the grain.
8) Oven not calibrated correctly.
9) Does not like rare/medium rare meat so extended cooking time or cooked roast again (failure ensured!).
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-04-03T10:44:38.88
helpfulCount:

text:
It worked!  I had my older son take the meat out of the fridge 1 hour before. I could't make it home in time so I had him turn the oven to 500, then rub a little olive oil on it and generously seasoned it with Montreal steak seasoning.  I had him keep it at 500 for the first section, (because we were running a little short on time). Then turned it off.  Only did a total of 2 hours due to time restriction.  During the last 20 min we turned it on to 250, just to make sure it was warm.  We let it rest.  The meat was tender, delicious and cooked perfectly!  This is a keeper.  The left over meat makes delicious sandwiches! PS We have a gas oven and it turned out great the way I did it.

This is a really great recipe for cooking an eye round roast. However, I have found my cooking times to be less than the recipe, so I always use a digital meat thermometer that allows me to constantly monitor the meat's temperature. Not doing so would have meant well-done meat in every case. Using the meat thermometer, I get a medium-rare roast every time!

This recipe is so easy its crazy! ONE thing: Let meat sit out to room temperature 1st. Either in microwave or on the counter. I made it the 1st time and it was so good the next time I made breakfast then put it in the oven, had a nice nap, and Voila! Done! It is a great recipe for me because I make my meat for roast beef sandwiches. Let the meat get to room temperature so the muscle doesn't tighten up.. The cooking on this is great.

It works! We had a 1.5 pound roast, and so we tried it at 10 minutes at 500 and then 30 minutes with the oven off, but it wasn't quite done. We put it back in as the oven heated up for Yorkshire pudding and took it out when the oven reached 450. 1/2 an hour later when the pudding was done it was perfectly cooked. Next time for a roast that size I might leave it at 500 for 12 minutes and another five in the  oven when it is off. Still, it got perfectly brown and had a great flavor. This was a great method.

text:
Mine came out PERFECT but I did not follow this recipe, I followed what a commenter (PJL4965) posted.  I preheated my electric oven to 500 degrees for 20 minutes before I put my roast in.  I also used a basting brush to spread gravy master over the top of the roast and seasoned with garlic powder, onion powder, sale and pepper.  I then put my roast in for 7 minutes per pound, then turned my oven off and let it sit for 20 minutes per pound.  Afterward, I removed from the oven and let it sit on top of the stove for 20 minutes to let the juices penetrate.  DELICIOUS!!!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Having ruined many roasts, I don't trust any method, but this ensures a tender roast nonetheless. There are variables to consider:  e.g. is your roast still cold from a thaw? is it larger or smaller? Rack placement in oven? So far, the best rendition of this is using a probe thermometer and not letting it rise above 130-135 degrees as it will continue to cook when it is resting and usually reaches a rare-medium-rare temp.  500 is too high to start and smokes out my oven if it isn't spotlessly clean. 450-475 is a good starting temp.  Also, fresh herbs and especially garlic will burn, so be careful when choosing your crusting herbs. The best coarse of action is KEEP AN "EYE" on an eye roast.

I liked the idea of a quicker high heat, however it did not work for me. Cooked according to directions in a gas oven for 24 minutes at 475 degrees. Internal temperature reached only 85 degrees. After reviewing what others said I covered the roasting pan with foil and cooked for another 45 minutes @ 350 degrees. This resulted in a medium done roast, juicy and tender and delicious.

text:
Pleasantly surprised!!!

I used the gravy master tip from previous reviewer.  Definitely added some flavor and gorgeous color.  When it was getting close to the time to take out roast, I put in a meat thermometer (should have done that to begin with).  It was below 140 (lowest reading on my thermometer).  I started to panic and turned oven on.  It overcooked.  BUT STILL... it was juicy and tender.  I CANNOT believe an eye of round was that juicy and tender.  Oh also, I baked potatoes in foil for the same time I cooked the roast.  They came out great!

My only reason for 4 stars... flavor.  The meat lacked flavor.  The end pieces with the gravy master were good.  The rest didn't have much taste - great texture but no taste.  I might try stuffing in some garlic next time or making a gravy or au jus to go with it (although I had almost no juices).  Don't forget to let the meat rest.  I cut mine a little too early.  Will definitely try again!

text:
I followed this recipe to the letter. Using a 2.24 # eye of round roast (electric oven) it came out great. I cooked it for 18 minutes and left it for 2 hours. I used garlic shoved in three slits I made, fresh cracked peppercorn, kosher salt, and 1/2 of a beef bouillon cube crushed. I had sliced it as thin as I could and the meat was tender, tasty, and warm. It was medium (done) and delicious. To reheat, I plan on making a beef stock and using the boiling stick, I will toss the slices in and let heat for a few minutes. It's important that the slices are thin. I'm not a fan of leftovers often but I'm actually excited about this one.

text:
This came out great.  My roast was a little smaller, so I only cooked at 475 for 15 minutes and then left it in the oven for 1 hr 45 minutes.  It was medium when it came out.  I personally like it a little more rare, but the flavor was fantastic and there was no fuss with thermometers, etc.  I do wish I had put the fat side up as another reviewer has suggested.  I got a smaller roast because I am only cooking for myself and hubby, so don't be afraid of this if you want to use a smaller roast.  I used a 2.10 pound roast, and there was plenty for both of us and I sliced the rest for sandwiches during the week.  Eye of round is a very lean roast, so you do need to slice it very thinly.

It is not super brown on the outside, but I don't consider that an issue.  The flavor, just seasoned with kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper, was perfect.
Great recipe!

text:
Tried this for Sunday dinner.  It's best to let the roast come to room temp. before cooking at least an hour. I did mine pretty much like the recipe for rib roast by Paula Deen.  I roasted  a 2# roast for 18 minutes at 475 the shut the oven off for 2 hours.  I turned the oven back on until the thermometer came up to l45, about 15 minutes.  Take it out of the oven and rap in foil for at least 15 minutes.  It also is very important to slice the roast beef very thin.

text:
This turned out great. I always read reviews before making a recipe but never bother to write my own. This time I will. I had. 2-1/2 lb inside round roast and wanted to end up with something tender and tasty for a change. This method worked! I did marinade the roast in a mix of 1 can of beer, 1 T steak sauce, 1 T Worcestershire, 1 T soya sauce, 1 T barbecue sauce, 4 bay leaves, 1 T freeze dried garlic and onion and fresh ground pepper. Put all in a ziplock and marinate for 8 to 24 hrs. I roasted at 475 for 18 mins turned down to 200 and left in for 50 mins. Let it rest covered with foil and towel for 20 minutes. Sliced it up and served with roasted potato/carrot/onion/ celery mix and steamed broccoli. With a little bit of gravy and horseradish, Best Tuesday night supper ever! Hubby said "wow this is good" and he is a picky one. So try this method and if you have a cheaper piece of beef, try my marinade!
Bon appetite !

text:
I would have normally roasted my eye roast at a lower temp, with water, and covered. I was very reluctant to try this and thought no way was it ever going to be done. Well, I first basted it with a little Wegman's basting oil, garlic salt and cracked black pepper and into the oven it went as per the instructions. At the 2 hour mark I knew the oven couldn't still be hot, which it wasnt. (gas) I removed it from the oven and turned the oven back on because I just knew it wasn't going to be done. I got the electric knife out and began to slice it. PERFECT! There was no need to put it back in for a longer roast time.I did slice it and cover with foil and held in a warm oven until the side dishes were ready. Will never make it any other way!!

I was nervous about this recipe, the boyfriend and I prefer our meat on the rare side.  I seasoned it with salt, pepper, and rubbed some garlic cloves on the meat.  My roast was 2.5 pounds...I cooked (fat side up) it 18 minutes at 475 (after preheating to 500).  Because we were short on time, I lowered the temp to 175 and left it in for 40 minutes, took it out of the oven and let it sit for 20 minutes, sliced it thin and it was perfect! Will make this again for sure!

text:
Made this last night because I knew I couldn't be home at dinner time. I used a 5 pound eye of the round roast from Sam's. I rubbed it with olive oil, seasoned well will coarse kosher salt, fresh cracked pepper and garlic and then cooked according to the directions. My hungry family came home to a delicious meal! Hubby said it was only lukewarm and had to reheat a bit, but the roast was beautifully pink in the center, juicy and easy to slice. 
I really wanted veggies with this but I didn't know if that would interfere with the cooking time. I tried it anyway and I was delighted with the results. I cut up yukon gold potatoes, carrots, and onion into bite sized chunks, tossed them in olive oil with salt, pepper, garlic and rosemary and then spread them around the roast on a half-sheet pan. The potatoes were done perfectly, the carrots were still a little crunchy and the flavor was delicious! 
Thanks for the great recipe. I'll definitely make this again.

text:
just by looking at this recipe i know it will be a success.i do a similar recipe for my pork roast.i also say if you want to brown first then go for it.there are details that recipes dont tell you.one key is you need to start with room temp meat.if youre going to put a cold roast in that hot oven it wont even start actually cooking it until that chill is off.could take up to 20 minutes..so to all the unsucessful reviews i say if you didnt start with a room temp meat give it another try.slice thin for a less chewey meat.you really cant go wrong..lizzz

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/669757.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tip: Before roasting, have roast at room temperature. I like to wipe down my roast and season it well with my favorite seasonings, so use your favorite too. Then I wrap it in plastic wrap and let it sit out of the fridge for a good 40 minutes. There is really no need to turn the oven down. Just roast, fat side up for the 7 minutes per pound and then turn the oven off, no peeking!! Do not open the oven door for the 2 and 1/2 hours! Spend the time preparing the rest of your meal or, go watch a movie! :D
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Without a doubt this is the best way to cook an eye of round.  Here are some tips I've read here or elsewherer
1) rub with kitchen bouquet before cooking to give a nice consistent brown
2) adjust cooking time to size of roast - 7 mins per lb.  However, if smaller than 3 lbs leave in oven for 2 rather than 2 1/2 hrs

Wow! Easy to make and a hit with the family! If my husband likes something new that I make, he usually says, "You should make this again."  If he really likes it, he'll say "You should make this every week."  Well, for this recipe, he said "You should make this twice a week!" I also served it with mashed potatoes and a terrific gravy recipe I also found on this website called "Simple Beef Flavored Gravy" by Sal.  Yum, yum, yum.

country:

text:
So, I could not resist buying a beautiful looking eye of round roast when it was on sale....figured there were plenty of well-reviewed recipes on my favourite website. Well, I should have resisted the temptation.  My piece of meat was exactly 3lbs (I whooped with joy)...I used my meat thermometer as well......BUT I think what the recipe failed to state was that the instructions are only good if it's a "fat"/"round"/"chubby" piece of meat as in a squat, short but nicely round piece of meat...my eye of round was a long and thin roast. So, it reached temperature of 145degrees BEFORE I even turned off the oven to let it sit. However, I FOLLOWED all the instructions to let it sit without opening the door - the result - the temperature continued to rise and I was left with almost a rock hard  piece of meat, no pink in sight, not even gray...all brown. So - what's my lesson here.... ALWAYS TRUST my thermometer AND keep in mind if yours is a convection oven....now if somebody can suggest how I can salvage this once beautiful piece of meat, I will stop crying... :-(

Followed exactly, but after 200 hours I checked the temperature of my oven and it was already down to 120 degrees with a 1/2 hour to go. Anyway... at the end of the cooking time it was only 125 degrees. Luckily my husband is coming home late so I cut a couple slices of the ends that were medium rare (even at the very end) and put it back in to cook at 325 so it will be done when he gets home. It was delicious though.

text:
Made with eye of round and sirloin roast. (Sirloin is more tender). Use more salt than you think - lots more. Lots of garlic and onion powder with salt and pepper.  Fat side up is important too.  I also drizzle with olive oil to brown quickly.  I’ve also made with a paste of Dijon, garlic, Worcestershire, salt and pepper.  The pan juices are very good either way- dip the meat in it after you’ve sliced it thinly.

I use almost this exact recipe for Prime Rib at Christmas time. I make one change, though. I leave the roast in the turned off oven for 1 hour then transfer to a platter and cover with heavy duty foil for the remainder of the time. This frees up the oven for side dishes and gives you time to make gravy too.

text:
This is a fantastic recipe BUT....you DO NOT have to wait 2 1.2 hours to open the door!  You will, as many have said, have a cold roast to serve and heating it back up will just overcook it.  I open the door when it feels cool, I mean cool is cool so why wait an extra hour.  After about an hour, hour and fifteen minutes, it's fine to open and serve :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I really wanted to like this, but it didn't work for me. I followed the recipe, adjusting the times for a 7-lb eye of round roast. I read lots of the comments before starting and therefore preheated the oven for a good 20 minutes before putting in the roast. I cooked it for 47 minutes (a bit less than 7 min per lb), then let it sit for 2 hours. I used a meat thermometer but it was a little hard to read it through the oven door. I think the meat's temperature went up to 150F near the end of the cooking at 475F. After I turned off the oven it gradually went down and just under 130 when I took it out after 2 hours. The roast was overcooked (closer to medium than medium-rare), which is tolerable. But the real problem is that the meat was very tough and chewy, even when sliced very thin. I will be going back to pot-roasting these cheap cuts of meat.

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This roast worked beautifully. I actually used top round since it was on sale when I went to purchase the meat. Reading others posts concerning gas ovens and realizing that my apartment oven probably won't work the same way, I did modify certain things. I used a 4 lb roast and seasoned it with kosher salt and pepper as well as some fresh ground dried rosemary. I used a meat thermometer because I didn't want to play a guessing game of sorts and set the thermometer to medium rare. I sprinkled all three spices generously and then put the into the oven after it had preheated for 30 min. I then cooked to the 7 min per pound and then turned the temp down to 220 (lowest my oven went...) and used the meat thermometer to tell me when to take out the oven. Let the roast rest for the recommended amount of time and this was hands down an amazing roast and I plan on using this technique over and over again. In fact, I went and bought a few more roasts on sale and froze them in order to make this meal again!

country:

text:
WOW super easy!  I used kosher salt, fresh ground pepper, then I defrosted several of those frozen minced garlic cubes from Trader Joes, and spread a thin layer all over the roast.  My oven does not hold heat so I followed other peoples tips. Roast 9 minutes for every pound.   I heated oven to 500, then reduced it to 475 when I was ready to put the roast in.  Roasted it at 475 for 27 minutes, then reduced heat to 220 for the next hour and a half.  Came out just a little pink - just the way the husband likes it.  I like mine a bit more rare so I'll reduce the time on my next roast.  VERY EASY, especially for a terrible cook like me!

text:
I knew instantly that my oven would NOT stay warm enough to cook this through as it has a fan that kicks on as soon as you turn the oven off until the oven cools down.  So after the initial high temp cooking, I reduced the setting to 220 and finished cooking until the meat thermometer read ~140-145 (I like rare).  It only took about 2 hours after turning it down to complete. 

VERY good, I was worried that the cheap cut I bought would not tolerate it but I am looking forward to some fabulous leftover sandwiches. 

Only thing I would say is line the baking dish with foil, the high heat at the beginning burned the juices to the pan. (I did mine on a rack and it was nicely browned all around.

text:
Recipe was great.  I had a problem with my oven, however.  As soon as I turn it off, a fan turns on to cool it off, so it won't hold a temperature for long like the recipe would like.  So, I started like everyone else, then let it be off for 1 hour then turned it on 200 degrees.  Told the husband to take it out to check it, but he forgot (I was at the store).  Luckily, it turned out perfect.  It baked at 200 for 2 hours maybe.  So it was in the oven for 3.5 hours total, I guess.  Next time I want to try it at 475 for the 21 minutes and then 200 the rest of the time until done.  I served on toasted french loaf with a homemade Au Jus sauce- recipe from another website- can't believe there wasn't one here.  Yummmy!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the rave reviews, I guess I was expecting too much from an eye roast.  It was certainly an easy way to roast the meat.  I added only a little garlic powder with the salt and pepper, I made no other changes.  I had a 4.69lb. roast and roasted it at 475 degrees for 32 minutes, then turned off the oven. When I took it out of the oven after 2 1/2 hours the temperature of the meat was 142 degrees.  The oven was almost cool, but I figured it had probably gotten up to 145.  The meat was a nice color and it tasted OK, but I was really disappointed that it was NOT tender. I'll slice the leftover roast on the meat slicer, let it simmer in the gravy and hope that it will be more tender for sandwiches.  I'm glad that it was on sale.  I won't make it again.

Make sure that your meat is at room temp before placing in the oven.  I cut that corner last time and ended up with an extremely rare middle. Display Name:
brhuston

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The best eye-of-round roast ever! I've used many recipes from allresipes but have neve registered until I used this recipe since I wanted to rate and comment. Mine was 2.1 lbs so I roasted it for 18 minutes at 475 after heating my electric oven at 500 for 30 minutes. I did use an electronic probe thermometer to measure the internal temperature to be sure. It took about an hour until it registered 145 degrees internally. I let it rest 15 minutes tented loosely before carving. Incredible! There were so many drippings I made a gravy in a seperate pan making a roux first then adding half the drippings and just making a simple au-jus with the remaining drippings.   Cook with the fat cap up. I did rub my own spice blend in as opposed to just salt and pepper. I did coat it rather heavily with kosher salt.   It came out perfectly med-rare. I can't wait for the sanwiches tomorrow.

text:
I have to admit, I was worried when I finally opened the oven and it was not really warm, but I got out the meat thermometer and the roast was perfect!!!  I took leftovers to work for lunch and my co workers asked how I made such a beautiful dinner, when I told them they were amazed! I have avoided eye of round for a long time because I didn't know how to cook it so that it would be tender.  The only other time I cooked it was years ago. I braised it and ruined dinner.  This recipe will save me a ton of money!  I can buy eye of round for at least a dollar cheaper than other cuts and much less than ground beef.  I bought 3- 3lb roasts on sale this week, now I will be buying more and playing with seasonings depending on what side dishes I make.

text:
Had a small roast just over 2 lbs for 4 of us.  Was skeptical about this recipe but gave it a try.  Roast was in oven for about 17 minutes then shut it off.  An hour later the internal temp was 155. We had put a movie on and there was still another hour left, as soon as the movie ended I pulled the roast out of the oven, the temp had dropped to 140. Heated up some gravy, sliced the roast, put it in the hot gravy to warm it up a little. Served with mashed potatoes and corn.  This was awesome and so simple! The beef was delicious.

text:
I followed this recipe and even left it in the oven for a little while longer.  It was delicious!  Perfect for me, but I like meat on the rare side.  My husbnad felt it was too pink for him so I added a can of beef broth to the pan drippings and put the thinly sliced meat into the pan and simmered for a couple of minutes, not too long at all.  You can see the color changing, so it doesn't need to be in the liquid long.  Then served the meat and used the broth as a gravy.  It was delicious!  Will definitely make this again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was skeptical but this was perfect! I wanted to report what I did for others who like me may be using a much smaller roast.  Our eye of round was 1 lb. 3 oz.  I preheated oven @500 for 20 minutes. Lowered temp to 475 and put it in oven to roast for 8 minutes.  I turned off the oven and let it sit another 30 min. but it was too rare so I turned oven back on to 325 and roasted for 30 min.  It came out perfectly seared and pink throughout.  I might keep it at 475 for 9 min. on a roast this small next time cutting down on the sitting time after oven is off.

The meat was delicious! My only concern was that when I pulled it out of the oven, the internal temp was only 115 degrees (far short of the target 145 degrees). The meat was cooked to the right degree of rareness for us. Perhaps it was my oven's insulation that caused the problem? We will definitely be making this again as it was one of the best roasts I've ever made.

text:
Very good - you have to try it to believe it. I preheated the oven at 500 for half an hour. I had a 3-pound roast and cooked it at 500 for 20 minutes (forgetting to lower the temp to 475), and then turned off the oven and let it sit for 2-1/2 hours. I used garlic salt, pepper, and thyme as a rub before cooking. Result: nice flavors and a tender roast done to perfection (a bit pink in the center).

text:
Years ago, I cooked roast with a recipe just like this which I had gotten from my cousin.  I had forgotten about it so I was happy to have my memory jogged!  I never salt meat before cooking it so I did not add salt, but added TONS of black pepper.  My old recipe called for cooking at 500 degrees for 5 minutes per pound and leaving in the oven for three hours.  Not sure what size roast I used.  Anyway, this is the BEST way to cook Eye of Round roast.  It's delicious with a horseradish cream sauce on the side!

text:
This is a great way to make homemade roast beef! The only changes I make are to give it 5 1/2 minutes per pound at 475 (but i like mine a little red in the middle) and take 1 packet of Liptons onion soup mix and crush it with a mallet then roll the roast in it. then do it in a roasting pan with a rack. Thank you for for showing us how to make great roast beef at home! note! make sure to pre-heat your oven atleast 30 min, and when you turn it off lock the oven door, and wait atleast 2 hrs before opening! this recipe really works!

text:
Like others I thought this would MAYBE be good.  It was outstanding.  I had a 2 pound roast.  I cooked it at 475 for 18 minutes.  Then turned the oven off and let it sit for almost 2 hours.  It was more on the mid rare side.  I had to bring it up to mid well for my family.  Believe it or not I did this after I sliced it in the microwave!  Still extremely juicy and flavorful.  I did smear BETTER THAN BOUILLON beed flavor on the outside of my roast along with garlic, salt, pepper and CREOLE seasonings.  Made the best au Jus around.  I poured the au Jus in a skillet added water a little bit more BETTER THAN BOUILLON and rice flour (we are gluten free).  Gravy was fantastic.  I will be making this FOR SURE again.  My roast HATING husband gave this a 9 out of 10.  He has NEVER eaten more than a bite of roast in 12 years I have been with him!  That says a lot.

Just a comment about this review, luckily I cheated and opened the oven door about 1.5 hours into the 2.5 hour wait time, I put my instant read thermometer in and it was already just between 145 and 150.  So I took it out and cut it, thank goodness, it was juicy and still pink in the middle, not too rare and just perfect.  I think if you wait the entire 2.5 hours without opening the door, you will end up with a cold roast!

text:
I made this for Christmas dinner yesterday, and it was awesome!
I had a 5 lb. eye,rubbed it with Olive Oil and seasoned. I put it in for 35 minutes at 475, then turned down to 175 for about 2 1/2 hours. I was going to turn it all the way off, but decided I didn't want it cold, so I left it on for warmth. Took it out,covered with foil till I got done with dinner prep.
I have never had one come out so good-when I started to slice it,the juices just ran. 
The one end was alittle more than medium, the other end was still pink, so it was perfect for the mix of tastes we had.
So tender I couldn't believe it.
 Definitely will do this one again!!!

If you need to eat super-lean meat, but hate how tough and bland, THIS is the recipe you've been looking for.  I made this using a 2.36 lb eye of round roast and cooked it for the 7 minutes per pound stated and left it in the oven for 2.5 hours, let it rest for 20 minutes and WOW.  I almost couldn't believe it!

I only used the McCormick steak rub and it has plenty of flavor for me.  I might try injecting with garlic next time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just tasted this roast and it was excellent. I am very impressed that such a tough cut can come out so juicy and tender. I have a 40 year old oven and knew that it would have trouble holding heat once it was turned off. So I baked my 2.7 lb. roast at 475 for 18 mins. and then turned the stove off for about 45 mins. I then turned it back on at 175 for about an hour. The roast came out medium which is more done than I normally like but really tasted very nice. Next time I will cook it at 150 for about 50 mins. I made a "crust" for my roast which had flour,bread cumbs,pepper(lots0, salt, garlic and onion powder in it along with a dash of montreal seasoning. This came out very nice, just remember to coat the roast with olive oil and only cover three sides. The one that goes down in the pan should not have any crust. I forgot and had a little mushy stuff under my roast.
One last note,my husband is from England and when I had him try this, he said it tasted just like his Mom's sunday dinner. Which I take as quite a recommendation.

text:
It was COLD! I took the roast out of the oven after the 2.5 hours, and the meat thermometer didn't register.  I cut it open, and it WAS cooked through to a nice, pink, medium rare.  But it was barely room temperature.  I had to heat the oven back up to reheat the roast to serving temperature.  And fortunately, we were all healthy adults--I would have been worried about serving meat that sat at room temp to anyone with a weak immune system.  Also, there were no drippings, so no gravy.

userID:
3160535
Display Name:
Caslon
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this with a 3.14 lb. eye round roast. I extended the 475F cooking time by a minute or so for the extra .14 lb.
It came out ok...a lot of the juices ended up at the bottom of the pan. I had set it in a shallow casserole dish with a small pie rack to hold the roast above the dish a bit. Juices are bound to leak out no matter.
I've saved the juices and plan on slicing the roast into paper thin slices using my Krups meat slicer, then put them in the juices to add flavor, then use Reynolds EZ Vac qt. bags and freeze for future Au Jus and rolls dip. I bought this eye round from Vons and nowadays it comes to Vons in a plastic bag the butcher has to cut in half and trim the fat. Also, I noticed this cut wasn't as red looking as I have seen in the past, lighter red. So...what I'm getting at is the success of this method depends on the quality of the cut you get and your oven's ability to retain heat. All in all, not that great a difference from the usual 325F method. I urge all to purchase a home use type meat slicer where you can cut it into paper thin slices or slightly thicker for dinner plate serving.  

All in all...a good method.
Previously...with the slow 325F method per pound, the eye round roast seemed to cook too much towards the outside, with the inside being too undone.  This hot start method seems to eliminate that.

text:
Absolutely delicious.  I followed the recipe exactly.  After the 2 1/2 hours the oven was just barely warm, but the carry-over heat in the roast maintained a safe temperature.  I sliced at an angle with a very sharp knife to help keep the juices in every yummy slice.  And the left-overs (not many left-overs) that made up my roast beef sandwich the next day made a very special lunch!  

One hint.  When slicing thinly, do it in the pan you cooked the roast in.  If any of those yummy juices escape you can recapture them mess free!

Excellent recipe. Thank you so much for sharing.

text:
This is a great recipe.  I followed a couple suggestions made by other reviewers.  I brushed some vegetable oil on the roast, then sprinkled on some Montreal Steak spice.  I cooked it on the high temp for 21 min, then at 200 degrees for 45 minutes since my oven doesn't hold heat well.  After removing the roast from the oven and letting it sit for 20 minutes, I sliced the roast and found it too red/bloody for my taste.  I placed the slices of roast back in the pan with the juices and cooked it for 5 more minutes at 400 degrees and it was PERFECT!  My son who hates roast beef said it was "okay" and the rest of the family loved it.

text:
I put my 2 lb roast in the 500 F oven for 20 min, 3 hours early. It was cold when I took it out, but cooked to perfection (med/rare)!  I have had only mediocre results with roast beef in the past, and always had to cook the meat longer than specified though my oven temp is precise. This recipe is easy, economical, tastes really delicious, and I don't have to WORRY about it! Next time I'll take it out of the oven sooner. Thanks Lyn B-will definitely use this again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Easy peasy!
   I read many of the 1 and 2 star ratings before I started my roast. 
   If I had to guess why those folks were not successful, I'd have to say any or all of the following facts occurred. 1) Miscalculating stove-on time to weight of meat. 2) Stove not properly preheated before placing roast in oven and reducing temperature. 3) Somebody opened the oven door for a few seconds to just look and make sure the roast hasn't been stolen by stove ghost! 4) Oven thermometer /temperature gauge is incorrect. 5) The cook is used to eating overcooked pot roast. 6) The cook's cutlery is too dull to slice paper thin pieces of meat. 
   I used a dual-fuel gas/electric stove and a large cast iron skillet to cook mine.
   This will be my chosen method for eye of round roasting from now on. -Kenn

text:
I very rarely rate recipes but this is an exception. The very best meal I have ever made, hands down. in 30 years of marriage. Followed the tips of reviewer PJ4695 --the most helpful positive reviewer.  My 4.4 lb eye of round roast was tender, juicy and tasted wonderful. Put carrots, quartered potatoes and celery in a pan, drizzled with olive oil and sprinkled with salt in the oven at the same time and they came out perfectly done. Think next time I will put them in the same pan with the roast. The drippings in the pan (added a bit of water in the bottom, under the rack,  before I started just to keep it from smoking) were so good.  Wonderful recipe!  This is now my go to  special occasion meal. Many thanks!

text:
I have a good remote oven thermometer, so I cook it for about 6 minutes per pound at 475 then turn off the oven and wait until the alarm on my thermometer goes off at 140 degrees.  It doesn't take as long with my new oven because the door fits very tightly and the temp comes down very slowly.  

Perfect every time.  I also use this for whole pork loins.

text:
The best way to make eye of round very tender and perfect pink color - I did paint the outside with Kitchen Bouquet and sprinkled with  lemon pepper and  garlic powder before it went in the oven and it was fabulous! I made some au jus  to pour over the meat - 1/2 C red wine and 1/2 C boullion simmered on the stove until reduced by half then add 2 T cold butter -whisk 1 pat in at a time - add in garlic powder and salt and pepper to taste --  slice the roast into thin slices  and serve   with the roast

This is THE BEST recipe for a roast.  My family raved!  It is now "my signiture" roast!   I usually make my roast in the crockpot with veggies.  I love the ease of a slow cooker - this was just as easy......only difference is that you can't just dump and run.......but after you turn the oven off, your free as a bird!!!  I was worried that it wouldn't be crock pot tender, no worries anymore.  It was not shred able like a crock roast, but - IT TASTED LIKE PRIME RIB!!!!!! Perfect medium pink throughout. The best part is that this recipe very basic and you can 'jazz it up" according to your family's taste.

text:
This was excellent. I had never used this type of meat so I was very nervous. My husband bought 7lbs chunk so I cooked it for 49 min and left it in the oven for 2 1/2 hours. One end was done the way we like (just a little pink part left) but the rest wasn't especially for my husband who likes it well done so I put it back in the oven and cooked it the same way for 14 minutes and left there for an hour. Done!  I also made the pan gravy  with 2 TBS meat drippings, 2 TBS flour, 1 cup water, and salt and pepper.  Slice it as thin as possible and it will melt in your mouth!

text:
This was FANTASTIC! I followed the advice of another who put a rub of garlic (whole clove mashed through garlic press) kosher salt, mixed up pepper(black pepper will do) ms Dash onion and herb, and some oil, only enough to make it like a paste..rub it all over the meat and follow the directions of preheat oven to 500 degrees, turn it to 475 when you put the meat in 7 min per lb. after that time is up, then turn it to lowest setting (170) at 12 min per lb. DO NOT OPEN THE OVEN!  Best pan drippings EVER! It smelled like I was making garlic bread. lol  The whole family LOVED this! Lots of flavor! P.S. The key is to slice it THIN! The thinner the better!

text:
Made this today and used this recipe, we love medium rare and this high temp recipe is one of the best ways I have found to get it right.  Ours was 3.04 pounds and I preheated to 500 degrees, BUT only for about 5 minutes, then reduced to 475.  It came out delicious but a bit too rare in the center of the roast which was about 6 inch diameter roast.  After reading thru a few of these, I'll try to preheat to 500 degrees about 20 minutes or so before placing the roast in to cook and reducing to 475.  It was seriously delicious.  Used balsamic, salt and lemon pepper on the exterior and it was great and not overpowering.  Enjoy!

text:
I made the following adjustments:  preheated my convection oven to roast temp of 500 degrees. Coated roast with fresh ground black pepper, garlic salt and that's it.    Placed 4.0 lb roast in it for 32 minutes as we enjoy beef with just a touch of pink.  Set timer for 31 minutes as a compromise to the "medium" 28 minutes.  Removed the 4 lb roast after exactly 2.5 hours.  Still couldn't touch handles of roasting pan with bare hands.  Wrapped in foil and heated veggies and made pan gravy.  At that temp and a 1/2 cup beef stock I easily had 4c of gravy added ramikin of flour and water to thicken.  Terrific gravy from drippings due to high hear I am sure.  All visible fat prior to roasting was gone.  Used cuisinart carving knife to cut thin slices of beef.  Served with mashed potatoes, corn, and Parker house rolls.  Enough roast beef to feed my two teenage sons French dips for lunch.  Win win.  FYI, I do my Christmas prime rib the same way.  High heat and turn off.  However, I have a really good built in double convection oven.

userID:
3607646
Display Name:
Jonathan
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6971564.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super simple and turned out great!  I didn't see anyone say how to cook two separate roasts at the same time (i.e. the way Costco packages them), so here's what I did.  I got a large cast iron skillet and put a layer of onions in the bottom.  Then I coated each roast in about a T of olive oil, followed by freshly ground sea salt and black pepper, and garlic powder.  I rubbed the spices all around the roast, but especially on the fat cap. I placed them in the skillet on top of the onions, leaving plenty of space between them.   I figure since they were about 2.5 lbs each that I could treat cooking two about the same as cooking one 3-lb roast.  So I put it in at 500 F, then to 475 F for 21 minutes.  I then turned the oven off.  After one hour I checked the oven and it was only at 170 degrees so I set it on 180 and turned it off again as soon as it reached temperature.  

After two hours hours with the oven mostly off, I pulled the roasts out and covered the whole pan with foil for 20 minutes before removing the roasts and onions for slicing and serving.   I then used the drippings (which there were a lot of) to make gravy.  The gravy was amazing, the roast was tender and juicy.  Everyone liked it best super thin, almost shaved.

text:
I was skeptical about this cooking method, a 9 lb roast at stake, and no backup if it flopped. Well, THIS WAS AWESOME! I took a chance. PERFECT! So easy. I'll admit, it was tempting to open the oven door a few times just to check, but I didn't.  Only used salt, pepper, and granulated garlic. I did lay the roast on a bed of sliced onions, as I usually do meats when roasting like this. Keeps the bottom from sticking. I've used non-stick alum. foil, but, with a non-stick pan, this works great. The au jus was fantastic too. At 7 min per lb, mine was a perfect medium. I figure I'd reduce it to 5.5 or 6 per lb and see where that gets me. Awesome as is though. This is a keeper.

I cooked it in an electric stove.  For the remaining 2 hours I kept the temperature at 170 as one in my family doesn't like pink meat.  It still was pink but delicious.  I cooked it without vegetables at first.   To solve the pink, I put it in a cast iron Dutch oven, cut up 2 onions and some carrots, put it back in a 350 degree oven for an hour.  It was perfectly done, juicy, and tender.  I'd only ever cooked with chuck roasts, but after this experience, I'd definitely cook thus again. I seasoned it with Tony's as I'm from Louisiana.

text:
I had a two pound eye of round. I tried the above recipe and when I pulled out the roast it was 112.7 degrees. So I started the oven at 375 degrees, put a temp probe in the roast and set it for 130. I like medium rare. It took about an additional 20-25 minutes to get to 130. I rested it for 10 minutes as I was hungry. I cut the  first two slices and it was great looking and was tender as advertised. So if you have problems with the roast not being up to 145 degrees, which is way over medium rare, then you can continue to cook it till the degrees you like. No problem. This recipe to me is 4 3/4. Luckly I don;t like 145 temp for roasts, so it worked out great from me to get it to 130 as I like it.

text:
had a 3.5 lb roast patted with Fall River rub and garlic slivers inserted.  Next time wait to put on seasonings until right before you put in the oven. Heated oven at 500 for twenty minutes and then pot in roast for 19 mins at 475 and shut off oven. Took out after 2 hours. We were disappointed in that it was really medium well with just a few traces of pink. It was tasty and not tough but definitely not rare like the picture.  And we wanted rare. This may be our oven or the fact the rack we used elevated the roast to right under the heating element and burned the garlic slices we put in.  Next time try 7 mins a pound and then turn off oven for an hour and a half. Will try again.

text:
Fantastic recipe.  My best advice is to know your oven.  Since we don't usually cook at such high heat, few of us have tested the outer limits, and this takes a leap of faith.  I know next time to drop the high heat cooking to 5 minutes a pound in my oven because we like our meat medium rare.  How your oven retains heat is important. I was afraid it would be undercooked based on reviews, but my WOLF professional works well.  There was NOTHING left for sandwiches!  Also used an A1 dry rub on the outside - the house smelled like a steakhouse!

text:
This is my first roast beef and i took the courage to try on this method "High Temperature Roast Beef". I am having a 5.2 lb eye of round beef and set the temperature to 500F (260c)for 35 min. I was eager to turn off the oven much earlier as it generated lots of smokes during the process. I keep holding it and shut off the oven immediately after 35 min and keep the roast in the oven for 2.5 hrs. The results really surprise us. Mid well with nice center pink and very juicy.Thank you very much.

Loved it.  Easiest roast ever.  Usually, my oven roasts are too tough and  crock pot too tender - falls apart.  This was perfect.  Very tender, but easy to cut.  Looked like roast from caterer.  I was nervous about oven being off for that long so halfway through, I turned it back on low (175 as another person recommended).  A little pink for my family and lukewarm, but perfect for me so I sliced off some for the cats and me, then put back in oven on 350 for about 20 minutes to make hotter and less pink.  Still very tender. Family loved it.

text:
I do tweak this recipe, but the basics are the same. I make a paste using 1T olive oil,  1T kosher salt, 1/4tsp black pepper, 1/2t rosemary, 1/2t dried thyme. Cover the roast with the paste (top, bottom, both ends) and I cook just as directed. I have never had a bad roast using this method!

I used a 5 lb roast and thought it had a lot of flavour. Not as tender as I would have liked and a little to pink for my liking.  I roasted at the indicated temperature for 40 minutes and then turned the oven off and left in the oven another 3 hours.  Next time I will add another five minutes to the roasting time at 475 and leave in the oven for 3 hours. The gravy was amazing.  My guests thought the roast was delicious.

text:
Loved it! My first time making a roast beef. After reading several recipes, I came back to this unusual recipe, especially reading that the rib eye cut can tend to be on the tougher side. I thought to myself, how can I go wrong when all but one gave it a 5 star. Sorry SBelle, maybe something wrong with your oven. Besides the s&p, I coated mine with olive oil and sprinkled garlic powder all over. My husband and I were quite impressed with the outcome. For the chew factor, very important to slice it very thin. We tried a piece slightly thicker and found it to be better on the thinnest slice.  The taste was also quite delicious, I must say. We were so impressed that I am going to cook a larger one for Thanksgiving and bring it over to my Host for dinner.

country:

text:
A REAL WINNER!  The roast I bought seemed really tough, because I had the hardest time getting my meat thermometer in it; I was afraid I would snap it.  I followed the recipe as written, calculating the correct minutes by multiplying the weight by 7 minutes.  I also rubbed some baked potatoes in butter and wrapped them in foil and put them in the oven as well.  The meat was not up to temperature at the end of the roasting time, maybe because of the baked potatoes.  I heated the oven to 325 and threw my green bean casserole in with all of it.  I baked in 10 minute increments to check the internal temperature.  After 20 minutes, it was all ready.  The roast was quite rare at one end, but the meat was amazingly tender and delicious.  The potatoes were the lightest, fluffiest bakers I've ever had, and the skins were soft and yummy.  I will definitely use this recipe again, including the baked potatoes and green bean casserole.  My family loved it.

text:
I have tried this kind of roast cooking for prime rib only in the past.  This method worked fantastic for this lower cost cut of beef.  I can't say it was "tender", but cut the slices thin, and it is fabulous for flavour.   For 1/4 the price of high end cuts, it's more than a great substitute, & don't be shy to serve to company!   .  Cooked to perfection med rare according to recipe!  Leftovers are going to be great sandwiches or hot beefI I put the raw roast in a zip-loc  with seasoning of S&P, Lawrey's, onion flakes & Worcestershire sauce, marinating for a few hours in advance, &  I wouldn't be shy to over-season more to your taste preferences.  It's all a matter of taste.  Definitely will keep this in the arsenal of my favourites and it won't kill the budget.

Display Name:
Biakk

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this with a 2.7 lb roast, an electric oven and a lot of skepticism. The meat did turn out incredibly tender and juicy for a eye of round. I cut an onion into large chunks and put it under the grid supporting the roast, with some home grown garlic. The fat drippings made the onions heavenly. The roast itself I rubbed with fresh thyme, cracked black pepper, celery seeds and then brushed it with peanut oil. 
No salt as it would draw moisture out of the roast. Additionally, I attempted to bake potatoes alongside the roast. The ones I used were small, about 3 inches in diameter. You will be pleased to know they turned out perfect. The reason I only put 4 stars is that, judging by my experience, the timing of the recipe is not flawless. When I decided to checked on it after 2h, The meat was cooked nice and pink, but the temperature had went back down to 120°F - it wouldn't have cooked more, only kept cooling down. By the time I had it sliced (1/8" thin with a slicer,) it was only luke warm. I had to layer it on a cookie sheet and shock it a bit in the oven in order to serve a warm meal to my friends. I'll definitely do this again, but next time I'll cook it 8 minutes / pound rather than 7, and then leave it only 1h30 rather than 2h30.

text:
I should have known better. When I saw that the end temperature was going to be one hundred and 45°, I should've known better. To me the way I like my beef which is medium-rare is about  one hundred and 25° because the temperature will continue to increase while resting.  145° isn't anybody's idea of rare except for the department of agriculture who want to make sure we don't die from some disease which is not not present anymore in the US. Especially if you start off with an oven temperature of 500°, 140° is ruined.   I pulled  mine an hour and a half early, and it was still ruined. By that time it was already across 140°

Display Name:
Susan Karppala

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4975645.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I believe this recipe was a bit too simplistic.  My 7 pound USDA CHOICE roast turned out a bit too well done for our liking (which also made it less tender than it should have been.)  This would have been avoidable if I had, had a thermometer with a cord that I could read outside of the oven. Unfortunately, this method does not allow you to use a standard thermometer until the time is up.  I dutifully kept the door shut with just a hope and prayer. I highly recommend people to make a purchase of the corded type thermometer if using this method. Ovens vary, (I am starting to think my oven runs hotter than it registers.) thicknesses of roasts vary,(mine was a long slender roast) and even the marbling of the meats vary and affect cooking time.  If you like your roasts rare to medium rare, you will want to know the temp of the meat. All in all, I can't complain. I'm not saying this is a bad recipe or that my roast was total flop.  It was quite good, if you like your meat medium to medium WELL.

None
text:
I had a 4.14 lb roast and had it in the oven at 475 for 29 minutes and then it was in the turned off oven for 3 1/2 hours because I got busy and forgot it was there.  It was still very rare for everything except the ends.  I cooled it well, sliced it thin and refrigerated it overnight.  The next day I add some au jus to the pan, covered it and put it in a warm 200 degree oven for about 1 1/2 hours.  I used salt, pepper, thyme, garlic powder, onion powder, and smoked paprika as seasoning.  The flavor of the meat was really good but it just was not tender.  I can't give it less than a 4 star because I adjusted the cooking times and that may have toughened the meat up.  I also used commercial beef because I ran out of my grass fed beef.  I will try it again when I get my next side of beef in.

userID:

Display Name:
bellat313

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was a real hit in my household tonight! I have made "Roast Beef" before but have always played Russian roulette with it in terms of roasting times. My family likes their meat medium where as I prefer to have it medium well. Tonight I prepared my top round roast with a dry rub that consisted of garlic powder, sea-salt, black pepper and red pepper. I place the roast on a bed of sliced onions in a roasting pan (on a rack) with about 1.5 cups of beef stalk at the bottom (I did this for moisture and to make the pan easier to clean at the end). I preheated the oven (a 10+ year old electric oven) to 500 degrees and decreased to 475 degrees once preheated. I cooked the roast for 23 minutes (it was just under 3.5lbs) and shut off the oven for 1 hour. At about 1 hour I turned the oven back on to 200 degrees for an additional hour. I then removed the roast from the oven and covered for about 15 minutes before carving. Everything worked out perfect! The meat was perfect all the way through (medium well on the ends and a perfect medium in the center) and this was a concern as I did not purchase the best cut (about a $11 roast from my local market). I will definitely try this again -  my family compared this to prime rib! AMAZED!

text:
I was skeptical, but I gave this one a shot. I used a beef loin, I had to cut it in half to make it fit in the pan, because that's what I had in the freezer. Since I cut it in half it came out to 2 3lb. pieces, so I used the cooking times for a 3lb. roast. Did the initial cooking before I left for church and turned off the oven before leaving. Came back 4 hours later and pulled it out of the oven. The outside looked like it had a dry crust on it, but when I started slicing it, HEAVEN!!! The beef loin tasted/looked like prime rib and was tender enough to cut with a fork. I want to try this again in a dutch oven and cover it after the initial cooking to see if that keeps the outside from drying out. Thanks for posting this one!!!
