text:
I have used this recipe twice so far and the meat turns out really moist and tasty. I generally tenderize the meat by using a vinegar or citric based marinade.  I follow the directions as above, except we like our meat a little more well done.  I do turn the oven off after roasting the 7min per lb, however after about 60 minutes I turn the oven on to 250 and cook for 30 minutes.  At that point I check the internal temp.  I usually take it out when the temp reaches 150.  I then let it rest for 15 minutes.

Turned out great!!  Was surprised too by leaving the oven off for so long...it was a little cool when I served it so next time, I think I'll warm it up before serving.  I had a 4.65 lb. roast, preheatead oven to 500 and then cooked for 32 mins. on 475 and let sit for 2 1/2 hrs. in oven and 20 mins. out of the oven with foil over it. Yummy dinner and definitely a keeper!!!!  Thanks for sharing!

Amazing!  Who'd have guessed an eye of round could be so tender, moist and tasty.  I had a small roast and, because we like our beef fairly rare, I cut the time at 475 to 6 minutes per pound.  The roast was perfectly done, medium rare.  The juices were plentiful.  I could have made a wonderful gravy, but served the thin slices au jus...to rave reviews.

text:
I was a little scared to try this, despite all of the positive reviews.  I've now made it 3 or 4 times the exact same way because people keep asking me to make it again.  Everyone who's tried it has loved it.  I use a different seasoning mix (paprika, salt, pepper, garlic powder, cayenne, oregano and thyme...add olive oil to make a paste and rub into the roast) but the cooking method is spot-on.  Just make sure to slice the meat as thin as possible...this helps keep it tender.
UPDATE:  I've started leaving it in the oven for only 2 hours after the cook time instead of the full 2 1/2 because I typically like my meat closer to medium rare.  WONDERFUL!

text:
I've used this technique several times, all with success. Brushed with a homemade browning sauce (basically brown sugar heated just to point of melting burning and beef broth cooked down to half), sprinkled with favorite seasoning salt and fresh black pepper. Fat side up and followed the times adjusted for size of roast. I did leave the oven at 500 degress for initial period. Rest for 15-20 minutes. Medium rare, very tender, and juicy. Easy carving.

text:
I am using this recipe tonight for a second time.

I have read some unfavorable reviews and the only comment that I may have is that my oven has a covered element which holds the heat & continues to cook even when the oven has been turned off.

Another comment is that I do own an oven thermometer that has a probe placed into the meat and then a thermometer that sits on the counter and I can see the internal temp.

I paint the roast with olive oil, add salt & pepper & use the Tastefully Simple Spices Onion Onion & Garlic Garlic.  Its outstanding.

I've used this recipe many times previously with a round roast. Just seasoned with freshly ground salt and pepper, little onion powder. Thanks Lyn for a great recipe!

text:
Awesome recipe! My new favorite way to cook beef, beats my old favorite meal of pot roast. Can't screw it up. My oven doesn't hold the heat well so I leave it on between 180 - 200 degrees for 2 1/2 - 3 hours after the initial high heat. Last time I made it had to hold it a bit longer so I just turned the oven off and let it rest in there for another hour, and then on the counter for 20 minutes. It was at 155 degrees and I was afraid it would be dry and over done. To my surprise it was great, very moist and juicy. Still pink, but not red, just perfect for my kids, who hate rare meat. I had seasoned it with the browning sauce, per another suggestion, and my usual steak seasoning blend of seasoning salt, garlic powder, onion powder and pepper.

I followed the recipe exactly and the meat was way overdone and chewy.  Very disappointing.  
I'm not sure if others' ovens don't have too good of a seal, but mine stayed hot after I turned it off.  I was skeptical, but trusted the recipe and all of the rave reviews and left the roast in the oven.  
Please use the meat thermometer and take it out as soon as it reaches the temp!

text:
I was skeptical about turning off the oven but I'm glad I did. The 5-lb. roast I made came out a little more done than I prefer (it was perfect if you like medium), but it was still juicy and good. I cooked it at 475° for 35 minutes and left it in for 2.5 hours as directed. Next time I'll take it out of the oven earlier. I seasoned it with coarse sea salt, cracked pepper, a package of Lipton onion soup mix and some fresh chopped parsley. Great flavor! I added a cornstarch slurry and flour to the juices and cooked up some wonderful gravy.

I was skeptical with the turning off of the oven but the 2.5lb roast came out very juicy though just a little bit more rare than I like my roasts done so I will just adjust it next time around. Also, I found the meat was just luke warm at the end of the cooking time and needed to be warmed up in the microwave for a minute. I altered the recipe in that I marinated the meat overnight and that added very nice flavour. I will definitely make this again but will increase the roasting time prior to turning off the oven.

text:
This was so delicious! Of course I seasoned it to what I was preparing and it was my hubby's favorite part of the meal! I made the roast Middle Eastern style *salivates* I rubbed the meat down with 2 tbsp soy sauce, 1 1/2 tbsp olive oil, 1 tsp marsala, 1 tsp cumin, 1 tsp cinnamon, salt, and pepper. Heat a large skillet to a lil more than medium high. Once the pan gets real hot sear all sides of the meat. First on the fatty side then brown the rest. I followed the rest of the recipe and the meat was so tender and juicy!!! Like I said, my hubby's favorite roast now (and mine), that's awesome. ^.^

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-03-21T13:25:20.143
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
3978833
Display Name:
Jenny Weaver-Beal
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
115
favoritesCount:
119
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2154059.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The cooking instructions on this roast worked out perfectly in my gas oven. The beef is tender and cooked to perfection every time. 

Instead of just salt and pepper, I make a blend of salt, freshly cracked pepper, oregano, garlic powder, and thyme powder. For spice, I'll sometimes add ground chipotle or habanero powder. I sprinkle it quite liberally over the entire roast and stud the meat with whole garlic cloves before baking it in an uncovered Dutch oven. 

When I pull the roast out, it always has a beautiful crust on it and about two tablespoons of drippings left in the pan. I sometimes add a little bit of beef stock to this to create an au jus. Other times, I'll make a pan gravy. And sometimes, I'll just thinly slice the meat and place it in the pan in order to soak up some of the juices. 

This roast is delicious!!! The roast beef is perfect for sandwiches or just as an accompaniment to a simple green salad. I can't wait until eye of round goes on sale again so I can stock up and make another roast or two!

I've read some other reviewers complain about the meat looking good but still being tough after preparing it this way. To that, I have to say it is extremely important to slice this meat thinly. I have a deli slicer that works great, but when I don't want to pull that out, I make sure that I use a very, very sharp nice to get super thin slices. 

I like to cook two roasts at a time so we have one for dinner and then cold roast beef for the rest of the week.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I loved this!  Cooked a 4 pound roast for 35 minutes and let it sit for 3 1/2 hours (since we returned home later than expected) and it was the best ever.  The extra minutes cooking made the roast just a little pink in the middle, which is how my family likes it.  The biggest advantage to this recipe is I know exactly when it will be done, instead of having to check the thermometer several times.  And it came out a hundred times moister and more flavorful that when I use my slow cooker.  This is the only way I will cook my roasts from now on!

userID:
6618374
Display Name:
Robert H.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually follow recipes that say to put the roast in a 350 degree preheated oven for so many minutes per pound while using a digital oven thermometer to hit the target temp but the roast always came out with the outer part of the roast overdone and dry with just a sliver of the middle medium rare as we like it. If I adjust the temp or time the outer part is still dry but the center is too rare. This recipe is fantastic! I followed the directions using a 3.87 lb roast, in a gas oven, except I did not reduce the temp from 500 degrees. I left the roast in for 21 minutes then turned the oven off. After about an hour and a half the temp was at 123 degrees (my target was 130) and then dropped to 120 degrees. I turned the oven back on to 180 and watched my thermometer until it got to 130 (about an hour) and took the roast out, and let it sit for about 20 minutes before carving. I could not believe how evenly the roast had cooked, even on the ends! I inserted slivers of garlic in the roast, then generously salted and peppered it. Once the roast was done, I brushed on about a 1/4 cup or so of soy sauce, letting it stand. Amazing how moist and tender this cut of meat is using this recipe. I will be using this technique on other things from now on, such as pork roasts and hams. Thanks for this great way to cook a roast!
Review:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had zero expectations for this one. Bought 2.3 lb grassfed/grass finished eye of round without a plan and then found out I can't braise it and if it's not prepared properly it can be tough and tasteless. Sprinkled liberally w/ garlic powder, sea salt, fresh ground pepper and thyme. Started in 500 oven w/ fat side up (very thin layer of fat), turned down to 475 for 16 mins, left for 1.75 hrs and got nervous b/c oven felt kind of cool on outside. Turned oven on to 250, when preheated took roast out and temp was 135. Put back in for 20 mins at 250 and then roast was exactly 144. Covered w/ foil for 20 mins. Carved beautifully. Not tough -- not butter soft  either but very nice. Try it! I was pleasantly surprised. I would serve to guests without hesitation as part of a buffet dinner.

Unbelievable! My husband Loved it, he said it was done to perfection. Never thought that a eye-of-round roast could ever turn out this tender and juicy! 
 Definately recommend this recipie! Mine turned out eacxly like the picture.
My Roast was 3 3/4 lbs  did the oven at 500 for 15 minutes turned down to 475 for 1/2 hour then to lowest setting (170 c) fo 2 1/2 hours stuck a meat themometer in and it said medium rare. Took it out of oven let it rest 10 minutes an sliced it thin and it made the absolute best Beef Dip ever!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not sure if it was my oven (I'm in a new rental apt.), but the outside of the roast was pretty tough and the internal temperature only was at 120 when I tested before cutting.  Make sure you know your oven well before experimenting with this recipe!  I had to put the roast back in the oven for another 15 minutes at 375 degrees to reach the internal temperature of 145.  I would definitely recommend testing the temperature before letting it rest to assure that it has met the right temp.  

I also followed some suggestions to add spices as a rub before cooking - be careful with the amount you use as it will overpower your pallet if you use too much.  Use a modest amount and let it marinate for a bit - trust me... the roast will absorb the flavors.  Otherwise you run the risk of only tasting the spices and not the meat. (Not a good combination when you end up with a tough exterior like I did.  We ended up cutting off the edges... what a waste!)  The end result was a pretty tender center, and I'm giving the recipe the benefit of the doubt, but rating our experience with spices and all, I would have given this recipe 3 stars.

text:
All I have to say is OMG!!!! This is an incredible way of cooking roasts!!!I was always hesitant to make a roast in the oven for fear of it being too dry. This method completely changed me. I used a 2.5 pound eye round roast and rubbed it with a seasoning packet I had from omaha steaks - it was dry bell peppers, dried garlic, salt, pepper, and sugar.  After I turned the oven off, I was very skeptical and let the roast stay in for 2 hours.  I checked it out and saw it was a tad bit too red for my household so I turned the oven back on at 400 degrees and cooked it for another 20 minutes.  The roast came out pink and juicy. It was the best roast I ever made.

Key to making it seem tender is to cut it very thin.

text:
FIVE STARS PLUS!  The best roast I have ever had.  We cooked the roast in our Le Creuset.  I think that had a lot to do with the success - it holds in the heat.  Many reviews stated that their roast came out cold.  It's the cookware you use.  If you like rare meat, follow the recipe exactly; if you like more well done meat, add about 10 minutes before you turn the oven off.  BEST ROAST EVER

text:
I did not have much luck with this recipe.  I was very excited to use it because it looked so easy!  However, my beef was very tough after 4 hours.  I did use an organic GRASS fed roast so I'm wondering if that made the difference.  Grass fed beef is extremely lean so sometimes certain cooking methods don't work.  Next time I think I would follow the recipe as is but then after the two hours I would put it in a crock pot and leave it for 6 - 8 hours.

I did exactly what the cooking instructions said and when there was still an hour and 20 min. left on my timer, the internal temp. was 145...after about 10 the temp started dropping, it never reached the suggested temp of 160.  So, I had to turn the oven back on at a much lower temp and the meat was over done.  I will not cook it like this again, but for those of you that it worked great for, good for you.

AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!! I would have never thought of doing a roast like this but this was GREAT!!!!!!!!!! My husband loves roast beef and every time I try to make it it comes out a greyish color all the way through and has the consistency of shoe leather. But this was PERFECT!!!!!!! I marinated my 3lb eye of round in vegetable oil and McCormick's Meat Marinade Seasoning Mix and it was DELICIOUS!!!!!!!!!! Crispy and slightly blackened on the outside, pink and perfect on the inside and SO MOIST!!!!!!!!!!!! I will never cook roast beef any other way ever again!!!!!!! THANK YOU LYN B!!!!!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mine turned out very good. It sat on the counter for about 15 minutes before I put it in the oven. I used a 2.5 lb roast, rubbed it with olive oil, salt, pepper, and garlic and then cooked for 18 minutes at 475; then lowered the oven to 180 for an hour; then 200 for another hour. It turned out looking like the pic -- medium (?). After reading all the reviews, I was afraid my oven wouldn't stay hot, so I kept it on. Next time, I think I'm just going to leave it on 200 for 90 minutes (longer if more meat). I also made a simple gravy; there weren't a lot of pan drippings, so I added beef bouillon and some roux and it came out quite tasty. Whole family loved it.

Wow I cant believe how well this worked, perfect. I used a steak seasoning and it was great. It worked perfectly the meat was thin and juicey, just like deli roast beef at a  fraction of the cost.

I'm still in disbelief.  PERFECTION!  I am absolutely THRILLED with the outcome of the eye of the round roast that I prepared today, just as the recipe/preparation suggestions recommended.  Tasty, tender, perfect level of medium-rare slices of roast.  I prepared same type of roast last week, cooking it as I'd cook a beef tenderloin, and the eye of the round did not come out well at all!  I was so discouraged.  Then, I decided to try it again, but with this prep method, and voila', it was well worth it!  A $14 roast tasted like a tenderloin that would cost $60!  I'm sharing the good news with my friends, and I have a feeling that the local market will be getting lots of requests for eye of the round roasts now!

text:
AWESOME! I never comment on things like this but this recipe deserves comment. I never imagined eye round roast could be so tender and juicy. It was a good as any prime rib [and better flavor]. I can't wait to make another! I added adolph's, garlic and steakhouse [grinder] seasonings to the rub. I was hoping for med-rare so I cooked it 8 min per pound. I was a little behind schedule so I left it in the oven for 2 hours at 175 degrees; it was a perfect med-rare. My husband said it was the best beef he has ever had. The daughter said it was in the top 3 of all my dishes.  My toddler cleaned his plate and he won't eat beef unless it's a burger or spaghetti. This so easy and saves time and money so I will be doing this a lot.

None
text:
My wife brought home this piece of "mystery meat". We weren't sure what to do with it, but it was on sale.  I found this recipe and decided it had good reviews so we gave it a fling.  WOWSERS! Fast, straight forward, delicious. Closest thing to prime rib.   Recipe called for sitting time of 2.5 hours. Ours was ready in about 1 hr.   I would strongly urge those of you that enjoy it more on the rare side to pull it at internal temp of 135-140.  One last thing that made us feel good about the cooking process is the electronic temperature gauge. Plug in the long needle into the thick part of the meat, set it to the internal temp you desire, set the alarm, and PRESTO there ya go!

I was skeptical too, but this really worked!  My roast was smaller than the recipe called for, 2.15 lbs, so I adjusted the cook time to 15 minutes.  I took it out after sitting for 2 hours and 10 minutes and it was perfect!  I used a spice rub of garlic powder, onion powder, thyme, paprika, black pepper and seasoned salt.  Also, I let the roast sit out for half an hour before cooking to let it come to room temperature.  Will definitely make again!

What is the temperature in your oven at the end of the 2.5 hours? I have a gas oven and because it is vented (there is a direct passage from the inside of the oven to the outside of the oven) the temperature in the oven really drops off quickly after I turn the heat off. After an hour and a half the oven temperature is down to 120 degrees F. I think I will have to keep the oven on but keep lowering the temperature to simulate the temperature drop in an electric oven. text:
This turned out great. I seasoned a lovely 2.75 lb grass-fed well-trimmed roast with freshly ground black pepper and sea salt, and roasted it at 475 for 19:15 (calculated that whole 7 minutes a pound thing). I ran into a little bit of a dilemma... I used a meat thermometer, and it read 140 degrees after under an hour with the heat off, but then began to cool off. After about two hours it was down to 113 degrees and so I decided to turn the oven back on to 275 and let it get to 145 before taking it out and tenting it for awhile. I have no idea if this was the right move, but it sure tasted like it. This made a purely delicious roast beef, even better with a little horseradish.

This was great. I wanted to cook a good dinner for my son (and the rest of the family) tonight before my son goes back to college from his long Christmas break. I picked up a 5 lb roast from Costco (first time I ever bought meat there). I usually tend to overcook roast beef but this was really good. I couldn't stand waiting (and everyone was hungry) so I cut into it and it was perfect. The only thing wrong was that it wasn't real warm. I needed to cook something else in the oven so turned it back on at 350 and the meat was warm after about 20 minutes. I will definitely make it again.

city:

region:

country:

text:
Excellent way to cook an Eye of Round. I was a bit skeptical at first, but glad i listened to all of the good reviews and tried this recipe. I let the oven warm up for about 30 minutes after I preheated, and let the roast stand for a half hour. I used a simple rub of rosemary, kosher salt, black pepper, and olive oil. The after resting out of the oven after the 2 hours was up, the roast was sort of cold, but I made a two-mushroom gravy and it heated it up nicely when served. It was a challenge finding stovetop sides to make considering my oven was in use, but I just did a twice-baked potato and cooked it for 10 minutes while the roast was setting w biscuits. Beautiful meal, everyone was very impressed. Will make this again, it came out just medium, I think I will cut time down to 6 mins per pound, because we like our meat a little more rare. Thanks Lyn!

I live high altitude (6800 ft)  I was afraid of making roasts anymore due to past disasters...often too dry or overdone.  Meats tend to dry out quickly here.  This recipe I have made 3 times, and as long as I watch the meat thermometer it has come out fantastic!  The seasoning tastes so good!

Display Name:
Mary

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would not go so far as to say this is the best roast I have ever had, but it was very good.  I had about a 4 1/4 lb roast.  I preheated the oven and cooked for exactly 20 minutes at 475.  I seasoned with kosher salt, pepper, granulated onion, and garlic/herb mix.  I put it in a roasting pan on a rack and put bacon strips on top.  The high heat made the bacon smoke, so I am not sure I would do that again.  Since the roast was so big I set the oven temp to 175 in case the oven cooled down too quickly (I have a very old range).  I left in the oven another 3 hours and it was done perfectly.  When I took it out of the oven it looked kind of shriveled up and not that appealing.  But when I sliced it, it was perfect.  Pan drippings (after straining out the burned pieces) made a really good old fashioned gravy (dark and flavorful).

text:
Wow! I was hopeful, and assured by the number of positive reviews, but still a little doubtful until the roast came out of  my oven. Beautifully blackened on the top and tender medium rare through the middle. This recipe delivers exactly what it promises, and with a very inexpensive cut of meat! I made this for the protein  portion of a wine-focused dinner with friends, and so, seasoned only with salt and pepper. The taste of the meat was excellent, and there was just enough fat (i did not trim any away before cooking) to balance out the tannins from a couple of big reds that showed. Thanks so very much for a great recipe.

userID:
3220847
Display Name:
baldwicb
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

26

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out really well, although I made some changes that I think improved the recipe. I used a 1.6 lb eye of round roast. I marinated the meat for a little over 24 hrs in the frig, which I think was the secret to the tenderness and flavor of the final product. I made a simple marinade of apple cider vinegar, dijon mustard, minced garlic, and salt and pepper. The vinegar really helped to tenderize the meat. I cooked the meat at 475 F for 12 minutes and then turned the oven off. I was shorter on time than I expected, so I turned the oven back on to 200 F after about a 1/2 hr. About another 1/2 hour later, I decided to check the meat since it was a much smaller roast than the recipe calls for. It was perfect with a light pink center. I might even take it out earlier next time. I sliced it very thinly and served it with an au jus sauce I made and with some horseradish. It turned out great. Eye of round is great because it is a leaner cut of red meat and is usually pretty inexpensive compared to other cuts of beef. For anyone who is trying to eat healthy but needs a red meat fix once in a while, this is a great option if you make sure it is well-trimmed of all excess fat. Thanks for the great cooking technique!

text:
THANK YOU SOOOOO MUCH!!  About 4 years ago, I bought an eye of round roast from a grocery store that actually no longer exists here. Behind the meat label was a recipe much like this one that I used and LOVED.  I have never seen anything like it anywhere ever again and have been trying, in vain, to cook a roast without making it tough this whole time! I am not one to leave my oven on low and leave for the day, and I often do not have the time to sit at the house while a roast slow cooks. This is a beautiful recipe for people like me who are always on the go, but still love the taste of a slow-cooked roast at dinner sometimes.  I use a LOT of garlic in my recipe though. Like many others I've read, I use salt & pepper, as well as granulated garlic powder, other seasonings, and a couple cloves of garlic chopped and inserted into slices made into the meat.

text:
I bought a meat thermometer (just in case) and ended up misreading it with my dim oven light.  I was a little disappointed when my roast did not seem very brown, but that was probably my fault, I forgot to adjust my rack before putting the roast in to the hot oven.  I should have waited a little while to ensure that it was still 500 degrees!  Even with my thermometer goof and the rack goof--it came out great.  It was the best beef I have ever had.  I have always like steak, because I can attempt to have it medium rare.  But I had never tried anything like this.  I made it for Christmas dinner yesterday--and my husband and parents loved it.  It is truly idiot proof!  I demonstrated that.  Mine was 3.49 lbs and I roasted it on high heat for 24.5 minutes, then turned it down to 200 for 70 minutes (20 minutes per pound)!  Will make this again!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1127584.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a cooking technique that I am very interested in perfecting.  I had a 4.1 pound roast that I did a brine-marinate thing with.  I had a recipe with bourbon, brown sugar, cilantro, lemon juice, worcestershire, soy sauce, thyme, and water.  I cut slits into the meat and stuck garlic in about ten different places and then floated in the meat in the liquid for 24 hours.  Then...475 for 24 min and then one hour in the oven with it off.  It rested on the countertop for 20 minutes.  It was a gorgeous medium rare (on the rare side) and the trick was to slice it SUPER thin, otherwise, it was tough.  I had to slice by hand, so it was super tricky.  But it was deeeelish!

It was DELICIOUS! I thought that turning the oven off sounded ridiculous but I gave it a shot anyway and I'm glad I did.
I left it in for 2hrs and turned it back on to 300 when there was a half hour left.
I think Next time I will aim for 1.5 hrs instead because I like it a little more red.  My guest preferred medium well and that's what I got so it worked out great!
I put chopped garlic, salt, and pepper on the meat.  My guest hardly believed that was all I put on it!
I will surely make this again.

This was really, really good.  One of the best recipes I've found in a long time.  I put S&P and some dried onions on the meat and had it sit for a couple hours in the fridge.  The meat was only about 1.5 lbs. so I did the high temp for about 20 minutes and then it sat in the oven for about 1 hr 45 min.  Then it rested for about 20 minutes.  It was rare, but very tender.  My 3 year old gobbled it up.  Will definitely make again!

I must admit that I had my doubts about theis cooking method, but this is the best eye round I've ever had.  I used an external, programmable meat thermomter during "cooking"  to let me know when it was actually done (it helped avoid any temptation to open the oven door!).  The roast came up to medium temp before 2.5 hours were up, so I had to let it rest for over 1/2 hour while scrambling to get the side dishes done - but even then it was absolutely perfect!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Most important thing to know  ABOUT  is USE  MEAT THERMOMETER....  the kind that you place in meat, BUT has a wire attached to an EXTERNAL temp read out box.  That way you do not open the oven to check the temp  of meat.  I made this using the tips from rhe PHL4965 review., since  I had the browning sauce he mentioned( Gravy Master). Just a note if you use that browning sauce.... brush it on, do not pour it on.  A light glaze will do just fine. A good  size sprinkling of  garlic powder, and ligh sprinkling of Kosher Salt & decent sprinkle of   course cracked pepper  over the top .Use more Kosher salt if not using the browning  sauce  . Rosemary fine crushed  would also work well in this.  I may add that next time..  Also next time I am going to get an extra head or 2 of fresh garlic. Cut each head in half through  the equator, then drizzle with oil  and wrap in heavy duty foil&    roast . Then serve rhe roasted garlic ( individual  cloves squeezed  out ) along side .

Display Name:
2goose

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Most people who complained appear to have an oven that didn't hold the heat.  I had the opposite problem.  Following the recipe exactly, using a 2 lb. eye of round, I heated the oven to 500, put in the roast, immediately lowered to 475 for 14 minutes, and then turned the oven off.

Fortunately, I had inserted a remote thermometer.  Watched the temperature climb and became concerned as it reached 125 (serving temp for a rare roast) within a half hour.  After a few more minutes I snatched it out, but it got to 145 by then - which is medium for a roast, and far, far too overcooked for this cut of meat.

It was chewy and dry.  I sliced as thinly as possible and served with a wine reduction to add some  moisture back in. Threw the rest away.  #1 - avoid this too-lean cut of meat for a roast. #2 - go with low and slow, watching roast temp (searing outside first, perhaps). #3 - always use a temp probe.

text:
Did exactly as stated. 3.7 pound eye of round. Checked electric stove oven with two thermometers for accuracy. At 500F thermometers read 497F. Inserted meat thermometer in center of roast. Cooked at 500F for 25 min. Turned off oven After 1.5 hours thermometer beeped at 135 F. Opened oven. took instant read thermometer in center of roast. Yep 135F.  (Note: all thermometers were checked for accuracy before use.) Took roast out of oven. Nice crust, med rare, but meat was still as tough as an old shoe. The roast would have been well done if left in the oven as long as recommended. I feel I did everything right. Roast was fresh and did have a layer of fat on one side.

userID:
26109919
Display Name:
Carol V
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe 3 times and all with wonderful results!  I make this cut of beef for sandwiches, to eat instead of deli beef, which has far too much salt, and other mystery ingredients.  Last time I made this I had a 4.5 lb eye of round.  I used the temperatures in the recipe - preheated at 500, then dropped to 475, and I kept the roast in for 25 minutes (about 5 min/lb).  I turned off the oven and checked the roast temperature - it was about 130.  I left it in 10 more minutes, temped it (140) and took it out and let it rest about 20 min.  It was a perfect medium rare.  I slice it thin with a sharp knife, and it makes a perfect sandwich!  ALSO  - it freezes perfectly!  I made a big roast so I can freeze for sandwiches later.  I froze it in 1 lb chunks using a vacuum sealer.   When I thawed it a few weeks later, it was perfect, and even better if possible!  This recipe may not work for those who like their beef well-done.  I think 2 hours or more would make a very over-done, tough piece of meat.  Check the temperature of the meat at 1 hour, and maybe set the oven at 200 so the roast will keep cooking until you have your desired temperature.  I will make this over and over again!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-09-07T22:24:51.867

text:
Followed the recipe to the letter. After the exact time prescribed, the temp was nowhere near 145. I put it back in the oven which was now Stone cold. I put the oven temp to 175 and left it another half hour. Internal temp was still only 130. I decided I must have a faulty thermometer and took it out, covered it will foil and got on with side dishes. After 20 minutes I cut the fist slice. Almost completely raw and cold in the centre. Back in the oven at a higher temp. The 
first slice was decent enough so I bit into it. Chewy and not at all tender. Now it's 7:30 and I have carrots and potatoes to serve. Very disappointing. I think this recipe depends on your stove. Mine is brand new and heats up and cools down quickly. I will go back to my tried and true roasting method!

text:
Just made it and it came out perfect! Honestly, I didn't think it would work. I followed advice from others. Left 2.2 lb roast out for about 40 minutes so that it reached room temperature. Cooked for about 16-17 minutes at 475 degrees, then used warm setting on stove for curing time. Adjusted curing time based on 3 lb roast calculations, roughly about 1:45 mins or so. Internal temperature of roast was about 140 degrees when done.

text:
I followed this and had the best eye roast. I did forget to turn oven down to 475 and it stayed at 500 for 7 minutes a pound then I turned it off.  Following one reviewer advise I timed about 15 minutes more per pound for it to "coast" and it was almost exactly that amount of time for thermometer to reach 135. I took it out and tented it and let it sit until we were ready to carve it later. Perfect. I did follow cooks Illustrated and salted it 24 hours ahead of time and wrapped and refrigerated. I got it out to get to room temp before baking and baked in on a rack uncovered. Spices were Penzey Chicago rub and maybe a total 1 teaspoon oil rubbed over it before cooking.  Perfection.

I had a 6.3lb eye of round roast.  I trimmed off all the fat except for the top side, but did thin that some.  Cooked it as the recipe said, 7 minutes per lb. (rounded down to 42 minutes) and rested in the oven for 2 1/2 hours.  It came out beautiful, tender and juicy.  I did a heavy dusting of garlic powder, onion powder, salt and pepper before roasting and the crust was delicious too.  My wife and kids also loved it!

text:
OMG!  I made a 3.2 pound roast in my "newer" electric oven (american) according to these directions and I was THRILLED with the outcome.  I truly think that the type of oven makes a big difference.

Our roast turned out succulent and moist after resting for 20 minutes.  It was NOT tough.

My husband took the leftovers to work the next day for lunch for his friends.  While I was packing  his lunch I noticed that the meat was still juicy (even though it was cold and straight out of the refrigerator). 

His coworkers asked about the seasonings.  This recipe is less about the seasonings and more about the method.

Thanks for a great recipe!!  You've made me look like a star!

I used this recipe last week, and it turned out well. I added more seasonings (garlic, celery flakes, creole seasoning, and onion. ) I had a larger roast, so I adjusted accordingly when timing the high temperature roasting.  I had doubts the roast would be done after the long cooling in the oven. But it turned out great - not over or under done and moist on the inside. I would make it again, and, if I did, I might shorten the cooking time a little bit because my family likes it more rare.

text:
I've made this many, many times. It's a great way to cook a tough piece of meat. We use several pressed garlic cloves and cover the meat. Follow that with a generous coating of salt and pepper. The high temperature will start the crust on the roast. If you like it rare to medium rare, only leave it in the oven for an hour and 15 minutes or so or it'll be too well done.

userID:
17606567
Display Name:

isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
97
favoritesCount:
236
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
At the suggestion of many, I went out and got one of those in-oven thermometers that goes off when it gets to temp. Definitely glad I did that because it never got to temp! I noticed it slowed way down and eventually stopped at 128 degrees. Luckily I was keeping an eye on it and after several minutes of it not moving I turned the oven up to 250. When it still didn’t move for several minutes, I turned it up to 300. I let it go a little longer than I normally would have since the temp rose so slowly at the end, so I took it out at 135. Sadly, when I cut into it it was well done. I will say, it came out very tender for a cheap, lean cut of meat- especially being well done. I think that was thanks to the slow cooking. However, I think it ended up cooked through (despite the thermometer reading) because of the varied heat at the very end. I would try this method again for a cheap cut, but maybe leave it at 475 maybe another 7 minutes before turning the oven off.
Review:

5

text:
I used kosher salt and garlic pepper and seasoned a 3 lb eye round roast in the morning, cooked in the evening. I did the high temp for 20 minutes. But, then I got nervous about the timing and the whole "turn off the oven" aspect. After about 20 minutes off, I turned the oven back on at 200 degrees (electric oven). I pulled it out to check after 1.5 hours of cooking and it was 132 degrees. I pulled it out and let it sit, so it went up to 140 or so. It was delicious and perfect medium rare!

This was great! So nervous about doing it,but so happy I did! I took the suggestion of the first review to put the “gravy master” sauce on the roast before hand as well as garlic powder. I wanted to roast carrots as a side, so when the 2.5 hrs was up I turned on the oven up to 425 and kept the roast inside while it was pre-heating. Once per-heated, I took the roast out and put the carrots in while roast was settling. Turned out perfectly medium-rare!

I Made this for the first time today and it was delicious and so easy. I pre heated oven to 500 for a good 20 minutes, then put roast in and turned down to 475 degrees and cooked for 15 min. (I only has a 2 lb roast). When time was up instead of turning off I set  temp to 200  and cooked for for 40 min.  Then When that was done I shut off and left in oven for another 40 min and it was perfect.  Served with gravy , mashed potatoes!!

Removed roast from fridge for an hour (2 lb). Preheated oven to 500 for 20 mins. Brushed roast a few mins before roasting with very soft butter & seasoned with Montreal Steak seasoning. Roasted at 475 for 6 mins per lb.....12 mins. Turned off oven & let sit for 2 hrs. Awesome. We like it a bit more rare so next time I will roast 5 or 5.5 per lb & try removing at 90 mins. But this was delish! Thanks for sharing!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the top reviewer's suggestions, and for the most part, they worked well. That included brushing with browning sauce, then salt, pepper, garlic powder, and I added onion powder. My roast was only 2 lbs, so I did 14 min in 500F oven, then left in oven 40 min (20 min per lb), and let rest 20 min. I would have preferred this more on the rare side; a little too done for me. Maybe the size makes a difference? The next time, if I use a roast this small, I will either try lowering the temp to 450F or cutting down on the bake or standing time. I sliced it very thin, and it's very good. A little more rare would have been that much better, though. Thanks for the recipe. UPDATE: Used leftovers to make Beef Mushroom & Barley Soup as well as  thinly slicing beef into strips and stir-frying briefly in pan that I stir-fried multi-colored pepper strips with garlic. Both came out great!

I just put a 3.8 lb roast in for 27 minutes at 500 then turned off the oven.  It's been nearly 2 hours and the temperature is 104F.  It hasn't risen a degree in the past 15 minutes.  I'm going back to my tried and true method of putting it in a 225F oven until the internal temperature is 135.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly, and preheated the oven for 20 minutes as suggested by another reviewer.  I used a digital thermometer with a probe that beeped when the roast reached 145 F.  That only took about 1-1/2 hours, so I was glad I'd used the probe.  It smelled delicious while it was cooking.   After letting it sit for about 15-20 minutes to let the juices reabsorb, I sliced it thinly and it appeared to be about "medium" - just slightly pink.  By the time we sat down to eat it looked, and tasted, medium-well.   I imagine that it would have been extremely well done had I left it in for 2-1/2 hours.  The flavor was good, however it was not tender and was way too overcooked for our taste.  My husband and I decided we MIGHT try it again, but only IF we can get a roast on sale, as I found that eye of round is no longer an inexpensive cut.  If we do try again, I will pull it out when the internal temperature is 130-135 F, but I'm not sure we'll bother.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My 2 lb roast had not completely thawed.  I dried it off and coated it with avacado oil and inserted 5-6 garlic slivers in small cuts the seasoned with sea salt, pepper, garlic powder and onion powder.  I preheated the pan and oven for 20 minutes then put the roast in for 20 minutes to ensure it thawed.  I did not turn the temp down.  I also inserted a digital remote thermometer and when it reached 148 i let it rest. I sliced it super thin and it was absolutely delicious.  I sautéed onions and celery in butter and when it started to sweat i added some flour and let that cook for a minute before adding beef broth and the fond. It turned out fantastic and all plates were empty.  A definite keeper

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out perfect for me - the whole family loved it and I will definitely make this my go to recipe for cooking a beef eye round.  I'm only giving it four stars because I feel like this could be hit or miss depending on your oven and how well done you like the meat.  I followed the suggestions of some of the other reviewers, making sure the roast was at room temperature and the oven preheated at 500 degrees for a good thirty minutes before putting the roast in.  I cooked a 3lb eye round at 500 (not 475) for 21 minutes and then turned the oven off.  I removed the roast after 2 hours, checked with a meat thermometer (it read 125 ).   I then let it rest for 20 minutes before carving.  It looked dry and crusty but was a perfect, tender,  medium rare.

userID:
6054618
Display Name:
SusieG
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
2763
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The cooking method worked great!  I roasted the meat a little longer than called for because preference:  Took 3.7 pound roast out of the refrigerator about 30 minutes ahead of time, then preheated oven to 500, at that temp for about 10 minutes.  Put roast into oven and lowered temp to 475, roasted for 30 minutes.  Turned off heat, left in the oven for about 1+3/4  hour.  Removed from oven, inserted digital thermometer, covered with foil and waited until internal temp rose to 145, about another 30 minutes.  It was still fairly dark pink inside which was okay for me, but if I had the same size roast I would leave temp at 475 for about 45 minutes to cook it just a little bit longer.  The only real change I made was to sprinkle roast with garlic powder along with the salt and pepper.  Next time, I'll add one or two fresh rosemary sprigs to the pan.  All in all, a terrific way to cook a roast - it doesn't get much easier than this.  One last thing - be sure to slice it as thin as you can.  I served with horseradish sauce and some blue cheese salad dressing.
Review:

5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great way to make an eye of round roast gourmet!  I  had a smaller roast, around 1.8 lb., so I cooked for 12 minutes at 500 degrees.  I didn't lower it down to 475 because I wanted a good browning on the outside.  I left it to sit in the oven for 2 hours, since my roast was smaller.  If I had a larger roast, I would of had to turn my oven on low for the last few minutes, because I noticed at 2 hours that my oven was barely warm on the inside.  I served the sliced meat with a horseradish sauce mixture of 1/2 cup sour cream, 1-2 tbs. dijon mustard, 1 tbs. horseradish, and parsley.  It paired so well with the meat.  I also rubbed the outside of the meat with a little more seasonings than just salt and pepper.  I can't wait to make this again!  Thank you for the recipe!

text:
This was soooooooo easy and turned out amazing!  I had a 4.5 lb roast so I cooked it at 500 for 30  mins. Then shut the oven off and let it sit for the 2.5 hrs. I think it could have been taken out at 2 hrs and would have been great too. It was a LITLLE more medium cooked then I would have preferred but I think my natural gas oven cooks things a bit faster so I'll have to adjust the initial high cook time to be a little less then the suggested 7 mins per pound. It was very juicy and tender however so I was very surprised at that! And there was plenty of beef juice to make a fantastic gravy! Thanks for this recipe!

text:
I followed the instructions about NOT opening the oven AT ALL after turning the heat off and my roast did not finish cooking.  Because of the injunction to NOT open the oven, I didn't find out that it wasn't done until just before we planned to eat.  I had to finish it up in the microwave.  
This might work for someone who has a better insulated oven and/or a meat thermometer that  stays in the meat while it cooks.  I think it might work for me if I transferred the meat to my slow cooker after the initial high heat searing.  I'll give it another try with our next beef.

country:
None
text:
After making this several times as written, it came consistently came out very rare, too much for us --- possibly my oven?  not sure......this idea is based on KacyBeth's review......This time we cooked it 9 minutes per pound, and rather than let it sit in the oven for 2 1/2 hours, it sat for 2 hours 10 minutes, then without opening the oven door, turned up the heat to 350 for the last 20 minutes.....took it out and let it rest for 20 minutes.....one end had just a hint of pink, and as it got to the thicker end, it went from pink to dark pink.....just perfect.....tender and delicious.

It still boggles my mind how this method works but it came out SOO good.. I ended it at a little under 2.5 hours and I could have truly taken it out 20mins or so sooner, It was pink on the inside but I would have liked maybe a little less cooked. I like several others used some other spices in the rub I used and the crust was soo tasty & delicious... 

I will def use this EVERY time as my go to method for roast. Only downside for me is I usually make a gravy and with this there is no juices in the pan...  But the roast is soo good  you dont need the gravy.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Honestly, I do not understand all of the rave reviews for this  roast beef technique.  Either my oven runs comparatively hot (which, as far as I can tell, it does not - it actually runs slightly cool according to thermometers) or I simply like my roast beef far rarer than the average American.

I roasted an eye of round subprimal using this method and it came out medium-well, light gray and pink all the way through.  It was, sadly, ruined - at least to our tastes.   We need our beef to be at least rare, hot red in the center.  I even tend to like it nearly "blue".  If you like medium/medium well roast beef, then this is a great technique to follow to the letter.

country:
None
text:
I cooked up an 8.4lb eye of round with a 58 minute cook time before turning the oven off. after 2 hours I could tell that my oven had literally no heat left in it so for the last 20-30 minutes I put it on at 200 just to keep a little bit of heat going. I still let it rest for a good 20 or more minutes afterwards and the meat was perfect and a great temperature. Pink and juicy just like at a restaurant, if not better. 

It made enough juices for Yorkshire puddings and a good amount of gravy. 

If this recipe doesn't turn out for you then you are doing something wrong. The cut I used was huge and super cheap. It should have been terrible but was fantastic. 5 stars for sure

text:
I made the recipe following some of the other reviews. I'm glad I did because I think if I left it in according to the original recipe it may have been over cooked. The change I made was leaving it in the oven 20min per lb after turning the oven off. I had a 3lb roast, so left it in for an hr and let it rest after taking it out. It was a beautiful medium, warm, juicy, and tender. I used garlic salt and fresh ground pepper as seasoning. I will try to play around with new seasonings the next time I make this. There will definitely be a next time :) Kids (ages 3, 9, 10, and 12) approved of the recipe.

Au Jus for roast - mix 1 tbsp minced garlic, 1/2 tbsp rosemary, 3 bay leaves, a cup of low sodium soy sauce, 1 tsp peppercorns, 6 cups of low sodium beef broth and bring to a low rolling boil for 30 minutes or so. Strain and serve with roast.

text:
Delicious. I purchased a 2.5 pound roast, on sale because it was approaching it's sell by date of 6/13 on 6/11. S, I didn't have much invested in this 'experimental' method of preparing an Eye of Round Roast. Well, I followed the directions but added about 5 additional minutes to the cooking time; because someone (who shall remain nameless) opened the oven just to take a peek. The roast was delicious but a bit too rare for my tastes, so I put it back in for another 20 minutes at 350 and it was perfect! It was juicy and flavorful and I only seasoned it with salt, pepper & garlic salt. I don't think my oven gets as hot as it should, nor does it retain heat like a newer oven. Anyway, it was tender and a hit with everyone, including the peeper ;-). He said it tastes like prime rib.

userID:
7073393
Display Name:
Mary
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
268
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Used a 4.6 lb room temperature eye of round.  Bound with string and spiced. Cooked on a broiling pan fat side up with about 1/2 c of water and a full onion cut into rings in bottom pan. Old electric Frigidaire stove. 
1. Preheated oven at 500 degrees. Waited 20 minutes, then turned down to 475.  
2. Cooked 7 min/lb for 32 minutes. 
3. Turned off oven; did not open door. 
4. At 1.5 hours roast temperature was 120 (probably rare). Oven was cold, and wasn't sure if an additional hour sitting would cook to the desired temperature.
5. Preheated oven to 180 and cooked for another hour. 
6. Let sit for at least 20 minutes.

Meat was moist, very juicy and pink.  Would definitely use this recipe again.
Review:
Rating:
2

I started out making this exactly as described but added garlic powder as a seasoning. During the cooking time, my kitchen did start to fill with smoke and I needed to turn on the fan.  When I opened the oven after 2 1/2 hours, I was shocked that the oven temp was not hot at all. My insta-read  thermometer showed an internal temp of 148 degrees and I became concerned that the roast was not cooked enough. So, I roasted it for 15 minutes more at 350 degrees.  That additional time was not needed,  as my roast ended up being on the med-well side of medium.  But, that being said, it was tender and absolutely delicious. The pan juices were dark and thick and delish.  My husband really loved it too. Will make again without the additional time.

country:
None
text:
GREAT FOR ROAST BEEF AND GRAVY SANDWICHES!!
This recipe is great to make Roast Beef and Gravy sandwiches for a crowd.  I buy a big 7lb whole eye of round from Costco.  Make the roast beef as per directions...except for 7lb i don't heat it at 475 as long as I should.    After, I let it cool and slice into thin slices and add gravy... any packets of brown gravy will do.  I use a few for a 7lb roast.   I add the drippings to the gravy and then layer it in my crockpot and warm it up on high.  Don't worry if your meat is pink as the gravy will continue to cook the meat.   It is a huge hit every time I make it for a crowd.  Serve with nice crusty buns, mustard and horseradish.

text:
This is the only way to cook an eye round roast. I live alone and found this teeny roast (1 1/2 lb.) but the dilemma was how to cook it since after 40 years of cooking I'd ruined many a roast. I heated the oven to 500, seasoned it with salt, pepper, and garlic powder. Lowered the heat to 475 and baked it for 10 min., then turned the heat off. Set for 1:30. It was perfect and even had some drippings for a little gravy. Delish!

text:
This was delicious. My roast was just one and a half pounds, so I cooked it at 475 for 13 minutes, turned off the oven, and left it sitting in the oven for an hour. After taking it out of the oven, I let it sit on the counter for about 10-15 minutes, but when I sliced it, a lot of the juices ran out. When I make it again I will let it rest for at least 30 mins to keep more of the juices in. I definitely will make this again.

text:
Cooking now...I know it will be delicious.  I put 15 fresh garlic cloves directly into the roast....just stab with a knife and insert the cloves. After 475 degree cook, dropped to 200 degrees for 20 minutes per pound.  When done, let it rest in the refrigerator or freezer to firm up and accommodate slicing very thin. (I use electric slicer) Heat up some aus jus gravy with sliced green peppers ....place thin sliced  roast in preheated gravy....enjoy

text:
I was skeptical because of the bad reviews, but encouraged to give it a try with all of the good reviews.  I weighed my roast!  I also wrapped the roast in kitchen twine and rubbed with a paste of oil, thyme, salt, pepper and 1 glove of crushed garlic.  I let this sit for an hour at room temp.  I preheated oven to 500 for about 20 minutes, turned it down to 475, then did 7 minutes per pound, then turned it off and did the 20 minutes per pound..  I mostly followed what PJL 4965 wrote (thank you!).  She also mentions to turn the meat upside down to roast as there is a slight layer of fat on the bottom of this roast and it absorbs into the meat instead of melting out in your pan.   When all was done, it was fabulous.  Tender, juicy, flavorful.  I was worried that it was looking too well done, but I resisted the temptation to open the oven.  I let it rest 15 minutes with Al foil lightly placed on top to hold in the heat.  I was really worried!  But when I cut into it, it was perfect.  We like our meat with a light red to red interior.  I'm a fan.

country:
None
text:
This came out perfect.  I cooked a 4 pound roast and adjusted the times accordingly.  It was pink, tender and juicy.
A few tips: 
Turn on an overhead fan, the oven may smoke when pre-heating.
Add sliced onions to the pan, they will caramelize and flavor  the au jus.
Cook the roast fat side up so the juices melt into the meat.
Toss quartered red potatoes in olive oil and your favorite spices (salt, pepper, onion powder, garlic powder, rosemary, etc.).  Lay flat on a cookie sheet on the rack one level below the roast. The potatoes will be ready when your roast is.

text:
My second shot with this recipe was significantly better than the first. PJL4965 provided the best tips - preheat the oven for 20 mins and specified the length of time for each step (high heat/no heat). I started the entire process for a 2.5lb roast at 1:00, and just left the roast in the oven until 5:30. It was warm, and tender when sliced thinly. For a challenging cut of meat, this is an easy way to make it taste delish!

text:
I really like this method. I heated my oven up to 550  and as suggest by others I let it stay at that temp for a 20 minutes or so. I then put my tied up eye roast in and turn the temp down to 475. I cooked at that temp for about 25 minutes and turned off the oven. After sitting in the oven for the a little over an hour or so, I checked the internal temp it was only about 140-145 so I turned on the oven for half an hour. Let the roast rest for about half an hour tented. The meat was pinker than I would like it but it tasted very good. Next time I will cook it about 9 minutes a pound as I like it just under medium.

text:
It's a nice technique , but it took me three attempts to perfect it. Each range hold heat differently so I cut the oven time by 15 mins . I rested the roast on a few carrots and celery stalks and a half of onion this gave the gravy a boost in flavor and it elevated the roast for even browning. On the third attempt it came out perfect. The first two roast were good but a little closer to medium for my taste and recipes that I used it for after the initial  dinner. It worked well in a Philly style cheese steak recipe and a French dip on a kaiser roll.

text:
My roast was only two pounds so I did this, and it came out delicious: I roasted it at 500 degrees for 14 minutes (7 minutes per pound), turned the oven off, and left it in there for another 40 minutes (20 min per pound as recommended by one reviewer). Then I let it rest outside of the oven for 20 minutes or so. I surrounded it with whole red potatoes tossed in olive oil, salt and oregono, and I gave the potatoes a 10 minute head start in the very hot oven.

text:
Pre- heated oven for 20 min at 500 degrees.  Cooked fat side up for 5 minutes per lbs and turned off heat.  When internal temp reached 123 degrees we sliced the most tender piece of roast beef you have ever tasted.  So fool proof it was embarrassing.  Don't open the door till your timer beeps at the desired temp.  We used a 6 lbs bottom round roast.  I will try a cheaper cut next time as many suggested.

userID:
15334718
Display Name:
Denise Delaney Yaremko
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2046994.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DON'T BE AFRAID!!
A FUN Experiment that worked out very well
This recipe proved to be a very tasty & worry-free way to cook a roast.
I bought an eye round piece--2.92 lbs exactly.
I preheated my electric, small, self-cleaning wall oven to 500 degrees.  While waiting for the oven to heat up, I rubbed the roast in EVOO.
Then I poked it in several places, with a steak knife, to make pockets, pushing  sliced garlic into those pockets. I sprinkled the entire piece w/ a generous amt of McCormicks Hamburger Seasoning (the 1 in the plastic shaker), sea salt,  table pepper, & garlic powder.
Then I put the meat into a square, ceramic roasting pan, made by Portmeirion--fatty side up. (Make sure the pan is placed in the exact middle of ur oven.)
I turned down the temp to 475. I cooked it for 22 minutes. Then I turned the oven off & locked it. I intended to leave it in the hot oven, in the off position, for the called-for additional 2 1/2 hours, but decided to open the oven at the 2-hour mark--30 min early. I was glad I did--it was 9pm on a week nite--my family of 4 men were starving, so I was dying to see if it was ready before the expected 2 1/2 hour wait.
The meat thermom registered 145.
We used an electric knife to cut it into 1/2" slices.
The meat was salty & crispy on the outside, beige (done) on the outer circle, & a nice circle of light pink in the center & throughout. 
And OMG, the aroma while it was roasting! A friend stopped in, & said "Oh Man, it smells delicious in here."
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-02-08T06:08:33.13

text:
I followed the recipe to a T however my roast was slightly over-cooked and came out medium-medium well. The flavor was excellent and my husband did enjoy it, but I couldn't quite figure out why it was so over-cooked. I have a convection oven that does hold it's heat rather well but even though by the end of the time in the oven my oven was cold the roast was still more cooked inside than anticipated. I did doctor the marinade a little bit by brushing on my favorite Dijon mustard and gravy master marinade with a little bit of garlic powder and salt and pepper which gave the crust a lovely flavor, not sure if that affected the outcome at all but I doubt it. Next time I will cook it a little less at the 475 and hopefully it will be less overcooked. Thanks for a great start on a new recipe!

text:
I had a 4 lb eye of the round with NO fat on it.  So beyond that fact, I also have a gas oven which, while not that old, is probably not that great in quality.  So I took the cook at 200 route for 20 min/lb out of pure fear.  Since every variation called for not opening the oven at all during that no heat/low heat period, I put a sign on the oven stating "DO NOT OPEN".  My younger brother apparently can't read well and opened it for about 2 seconds.  The roast turned out great (considering there was no fat).  But I guess I'll have to re-do this again to see if that minor change in heat made a difference or not :)

text:
I tried this for the 1st time today.  I usually cook mine in a slow cooker and it always comes out so juicy and literally falls apart but I wanted a nice roast that I cold slice and have for dinner and then use left overs for sandwiches... I have a fairly new gas stove (1 1/2 years old) and this did not hold the temperature.  I followed it exactly and after 1 hour was skeptical.  I usually can feel how hot the oven is when I touch the outside and this felt cold.  I am glad I did because it was not even cooking.  Disappointed as it had a lot of great reviews but obviously my stove does not hold the heat like others do.

text:
I used a 2.9 pound top round cut instead of an eye round. i pulled the roast out of the oven at 130 degrees - medium rare  - and it was delicious. I use a Thermapen to test the temperature and do not depend on a timer.  My only surprise was the roast which went into the oven at 40 degrees was cooked to 130 degrees within the 21 minutes on 500 and then only 40 more minutes in the oven with the temp turned off.  I was not ready with the rest of the meal as I thought I had two hours to wait.  But we worked fast and made it all work. Maybe my oven held the high temperature more than others??

OK, this is what happens when one screws up on a simple recipe!  I misjudged the weight of the meat and cooked it up front for a lesser amount of time (I guessed it at 2 lbs, husband says it was 7 pounds).  I followed the recipe to a "T".  Guess what, it still turned out wonderful!  I just sliced it extra thin in case it would be tough.  It was tender and succulent.  This recipe is a keeper!!  Not many recipes will tolerate someone to screw up and allow the outcome to still be perfect.

Prepared the beef on the gas barbecue... Since the grill unit is considerably less insulated than a common oven, some cooking adjustments were needed. Following the high heat blast, the gas was turned to its lowest setting for 60m minutes, then shutoff completely thereafter. This recipe is a real keeper; however, no method of preparation can transform eye of round into prime rib! — Skip.

text:
I tried this for the first time today. I should have read the reviews before though. I heard about it at the hairdressors and was very excited. I followed all the stpes for a 3 pound Eye-of-the-Round Roast. It smelled wonderful in the early stages, but lost any aroma as the time passed. When the 3 hours were up I took my roast out. All of my sides were ready to go, unfortunatly my roast was only at 100 degrees F. I couldn't figure out what I had done wrong, then realized I have a gas oven, which does not hold the heat!!! We sliced it very thin, and had dinner, it was very tasty and every one enjoyed it! I think after reading other reviews the next time I will either add a little low hear for the last 45 minutes or so. But will defiantly do thins again. I like the ease of it and the fact that I am saving energy!

text:
I tried this recipe yesterday for a Sunday dinner.  I followed the recipe to the minute, and although it was very tasty, I did find it a little chewy and slightly tough!  My roast was 4lbs. and I did it at 475degrees for 28 minutes and then 2 1/2 hours with the oven off. It looks pretty much like your photo, but it was a little tough. I don't have a slicer, so my slices were as thin as I could get them with my carving knife.  Any ideas or suggestions??  What can I do with the leftovers? If I re-heat it'll only toughen the meat more, yet there is too much left to simply throw away.
Please help!!!!

text:
This roast was perfect, I made it for ccompany and there was none left by the end of dinner. I love working with spices so I used seasoned salt, an all in onespice, and garlic powder. I also rubbed a little of canola oil on it. Remember to modify the time based on size. My roast was slightly smaller so I kept it in the oven for 2 hours. I added the pan drippings to a brown gravy mix and it tasted authentic, not like a mix was used. Enjoy!!

text:
I was really excited about trying this recipe BUT it was not successful for me.  I have a gas oven.  I followed the instructions using a 5.5 pound eye of the round and cooked it for 39 minutes at 475.  I then turned the oven off and let it sit for 2.5 hours.  When I opened the oven and inserted the meat thermometer, it only registered 120 degrees.
I managed to salvage dinner by reheating the oven to 500 and cooking the meat for another 40 minutes.  It was still somewhat juicy and tender.
  I'd like to try it again if I can get some suggestions on cooking it right the next time.

text:
WOW! Need I say more. I tried this last night while someone I am dating was coming over to meet some of my friends. Of course I wanted to impress every one, and I did. I did cook the 3.10 pound roast for 23 minutes, and like others said I was skeptical of it being undercooked. It came out like the photo, and the only thing that i can suggest is after cutting it to let the blood drain out. I felt that looked unappealing, but the meat was medium to medium-rare after it drained. I did prep it with olive oil, pepper, and sea salt. In addition, I cut slits in the meat and stuffed sliced of fresh garlic into them. Completed the menu with oven roast potatoes (canned) marinated in olive oil, sea salt and rosemary. (which i cooked in the toaster oven for about an hour, then boiled for a little after. What a great pairing. Serve with Merlot, it brings out the flavor!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wish I could give this 4.5 stars, but it's not possible. 
The cooking method worked out pretty well as a base. It does seem like the roast might need to be marinated before cooking, but it wasn't terribly bland or anything. Also, the meat wasn't perfectly tender, but still fairly tender.
While the roast was cooked properly at the end, it may be somewhat cold. We weren't sure about reheating so we just piled on the hot gravy made from the drippings.

Tips: If you cut your own roast from a larger piece, figure out the weight by multiplying the weight of the original piece you bought (marked on package) by the fraction you are using. If you forget to do this, you can also try to use bags of frozen vegetables to try to estimate the weight.
It's also probably best to keep the big strip of fat on the top of the roast when cooking so that the fat can go into the meat when cooking.

text:
For those of us who cook at high-altitude.  Was skeptical about the high temp strategy as the temp is lower at altitude, but this is how it worked.  Cooked at 500 for 7 minutes per pound and at 200 for 20 minutes per pound.  I spread paste of garlic, red onion, herbs de provence, olive oil and salt & pepper all over and held at room temp for an hour before putting into the oven.  Sliced thinly and it was delicious!  Hardly any drippings, so used butter, flour, chicken stock and few Tbs condensed mushroom soup - about half a can.  Little worcestershire sauce too.  Yum!

text:
When I first stumbled upon this recipe I was perplexed.  The thermodynamics at play here are amazing.  This turned out great and came out somewhere between medium rare and rare.  

I made a few changes - I used about 3 cloves of garlic, made slits into the meat and stuffed them into the roast.  I also tied the roast as it was a little malformed.  

An important suggestion - make sure you put the fatty side up so it melts into the meat.

Next time I think I will try this with montreal steak seasoning!

I'm wondering if a more insulted dish would help or if I covered it.  Curious if anyone has any suggestions about this because I LOVE this recipe.  Thanks.

text:
I was just as nervous as everyone else about the whole "turn the oven off and let it sit" thing. Mostly because I just didn't trust my oven. So after about 2 hours with the oven off, I turned it back on at 300 for the last 30 minutes, then took it out and let it rest for 20 minutes under foil. It turned out absolutely perfect. Very pink, but not too rare for everyone. I will definitely use this method every time from now on. Awesome.

text:
Don't do what I did :) I was worried the meat would come out cold, on the medium rare side and the hubby or kids would open the door. I preheated to 500, dropped to 475 then lowered to 250, when the thermometer read 155 I took it out and tented it.  BIG MISTAKE, it came out dry and tough which was completely my fault for 'over-thinking' this. Might have been ok at 180-200 but 250 was just too high. Next time I will cook per directions without concern! The only thing I did do right was to turn the exhaust fan on high, the ceiling fan on high and open the kitchen window, at 475 it got pretty smoky in the kitchen.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am giving this 4 stars because of the cooking method not really the flavor of the beef. I have a great GE Profile over that has a probe as well so periodically I would just turn the probe on to check the meat temp. It mas at 145* in about 45 minutes. My Eye Round was 3.5lbs. I did like the sear it gets on the outside and the fat side UP is a MUST! If your oven holds heat, watch this beef. ...................That being said, the flavor was just ok. I have a go to rub that is so simple yet so delish that I still can't believe I use it. An old beef farmer gave it to me after I had the best roast on the grill I EVER had. All it is is meat tenderizer over the entire piece of beef and then cover the whole thins in season salt. THAT'S IT!!!!!! I usually use that on steaks and strip's and what not but it would have been PERFECT here! Thanks for a new technique though with my roast. I liked that aspect.

text:
This recipe is good but I think it's really calling out for garlic! I make a paste of garlic powder, onion powder, salt & pepper and olive oil. Smear it all over the roast and wrap it in plastic wrap. Let it sit for a few hours or overnite. I put it on my rottis - 475 at 15 mins per pound. Then take it off & wrap in foil for 20 -25 mins. Sliced thin on sourdough bread with horseradish sauce & pickled onion- doesn't get much better than this!

text:
I'm not a huge roast fan and this was my first attempt at making one on my own.  Turned out perfect!  And, my husband even opened the oven door once before I explained to him that he needed to resist the temptation.  I had a 3.5 lb roast.  I asked my husband if he'd like to cook it or if I should make an attempt.  He said go for it!  I rubbed my roast with kosher salt, pepper, garlic powder, Italian seasoning and paprika.  Cooked for 24 minutes and then turned off oven for 3 hours.  Roast turned out a wonderful medium.  My guests - which were family - told me it was wonderful.  And, even my husband, who is a career chef, told me it was really good.  That's a huge compliment from him!  Usually he's critical of EVERYTHING he eats!

This came out great! I was scared also since this was my first roast I'd ever done. I did change some things though. I found another recipe similiar and kind of mixed the 2 together. I put the oven at 500, then turned down to 475 when I put the meat in, then cooked for 21 min, turned off oven and cooked more 20 min per pound. I also added a bunch more seasonings. Took and hour and came out great!!!! Perfect pink throughout! Will be making this again for sure.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Decided to make this for Thanksgiving dinner as my son had requested roast beef and gravy.  I should have listened to my instinct but got swayed by all the positive reviews.  First of all, I did not use eye-of-round but rather a sirloin tip roast.  I brushed it with olive oil and made a rub with onion powder, onion salt, garlic powder and black pepper.  As I was worried about having rare meat which I do not like, I cooked it 9 min/lb and turned down the heat to 200 degrees F for 1/2 hour and then left it in the oven for the remaining 2 hours.  It was quite raw and the few end pieces we could eat were too chewy for us.  It went back in the oven for an hour at 350 degrees F for an hour (meant to leave in in only 1/2 hour but forgot about it and cooked it longer).  It was quite well done but not chewy and actually quite tasty.  I may try a variation on the high temperature method by cooking much longer by pound and reducing oven off time.

I too was worried that tonights dinner would be a disaster however was pleasantly surprised by how wonderful this turned out!  I cooked it as recommended by PJL4965 ( preheat oven to 500 - then cook at 475 degrees for 20 mins, 7 mins per lb thereafter, and then let it sit for 20 mins on the counter.)  The roast came out perfectly, medium rare, and was enjoyed by everyone! This is definately a keeper and will be highly recommended !

text:
Before making this recipe, you should know whether your oven retains heat well or not.  Apparently mine doesn't and the roast was far from even being rare after sitting 3 hours in the oven.  I'll definetely make this again, though next time I'm going to turn my oven from 500 to 250 and see what happens.
